name: Ab Wheel Rollout
description: Kneel on the floor with an ab wheel (or barbell) in front of you. Roll the wheel forward, extending your body while keeping your core tight and back straight. Go as far as you can without your lower back arching, then roll back to the starting position.

name: Active Pigeon Pose
description: From pigeon pose position, engage your glutes and core to actively press your front shin into the ground while lifting your torso tall. Pulse or rock gently to create movement rather than holding statically. You can add torso rotations, reaching arms overhead, or shifting weight forward and back. This active version builds strength while opening the hips.

name: Advanced Tuck Back Lever
description: The second back lever progression with hips extended. Get into a tuck back lever position (inverted, back parallel to ground, arms straight behind you). Instead of a tight tuck, extend your hips so your thighs point outward from your body at roughly 90 degrees. Knees remain bent. This increased lever arm makes it significantly harder than basic tuck. Keep your back flat, arms straight, and shoulders actively supporting the position. This requires good shoulder extension flexibility and considerable strength. Hold for time, building up to 10-15 seconds before attempting straddle progression.

name: Advanced Tuck Front Lever
description: The second front lever progression, harder than tuck but easier than straddle. Get into a tuck front lever position (back parallel to ground, arms straight). Instead of a tight tuck with knees at chest, extend your hips so your thighs are perpendicular to your torso - creating a 90-degree angle at your hips. Knees remain bent, but the increased hip extension makes this significantly harder than the basic tuck. Hold with straight arms, back flat and parallel to ground. Focus on lat engagement and core tension. This progression bridges the gap between tuck and straddle front lever. Hold for time, working up to 10-15 seconds before progressing.

name: Advanced Tuck Planche
description: The progression between tuck planche and straddle planche. Get into a tuck planche position (feet off ground, arms straight, knees tucked). Instead of keeping knees at chest, extend your hips back so your thighs point behind you while keeping knees bent. Your back should flatten out, creating a more horizontal body position. This significantly increases the lever arm and difficulty. Maintain the forward lean, straight arms, and protracted shoulders. The flatter your back, the harder it becomes. Work toward 10-15 second holds before progressing to straddle planche. This builds the specific strength needed for the straighter body positions.

name: Alternating Hand to Foot Crunch
description: Lie on your back with legs extended and arms at your sides. Crunch up while bringing one knee toward your chest and reaching the opposite hand toward that foot. Lower and repeat on the other side, alternating continuously. This works both the abs and obliques with a cross-body movement.

name: Alternating Leg Raise
description: Lie on your back with one foot flat on the floor (knee bent) and the other leg extended. Keep your hands by your sides or under your lower back. Raise the extended leg up toward the ceiling, then lower it back down with control, keeping it straight. Complete all reps on one side before switching. This variation is easier than double leg raises and great for building core strength.

name: Alternating Toe Taps (Floor Taps)
description: A controlled dead bug progression exercise. Lie on your back with knees bent at 90 degrees, feet lifted so your shins are parallel to the ceiling (tabletop position). Your lower back should maintain its natural curve - not pressed flat, not excessively arched. Place hands on your hip bones to monitor for any pelvic movement. Engage your deep core by gently drawing your belly button toward your spine. MAINTAINING this core engagement and keeping your pelvis completely still, slowly lower ONE foot toward the floor until your toe lightly taps the ground, then return to the starting position. Repeat with the other leg. The KEY is keeping your lower back and pelvis absolutely stable - there should be NO rocking, NO arching, NO flattening as your legs move. If you feel your back changing position, you're lowering too fast or too far. Move with CONTROL - take 2-3 seconds to lower, tap, and return. Each toe tap = 1 rep. Alternate legs throughout.

name: American Kettlebell Swing
description: The overhead kettlebell swing that takes the bell all the way above your head. Start with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell on the floor in front of you. Hike the kettlebell back between your legs, hinging at the hips with a flat back. Explosively drive your hips forward, using the momentum to swing the kettlebell overhead until your arms are fully extended and the bell is directly above your shoulders. Control the descent, letting gravity and hip hinge absorb the swing. Unlike Russian swings (chest height), the American swing requires full shoulder mobility and core control at the top. Master Russian swings first before progressing to this variation.

name: Arch Hang
description: Hang from a pull-up bar with arms fully extended. Depress and retract your shoulder blades, pulling your chest toward the bar slightly while keeping arms straight. Hold this active hang position. Focus on engaging your lats and keeping shoulders away from ears.

name: Archer Pull-up
description: A unilateral pull-up variation that shifts most of the work to one arm. Use a wide grip on the bar. Pull yourself up while shifting your body toward one hand - the working arm bends fully while the other arm stays mostly straight, extending out to the side like drawing a bow. Your body moves diagonally toward the working arm. Lower with control and repeat on the same side, or alternate sides. This progression builds toward one-arm pull-ups by training each arm to handle more of the load. Keep the straight arm engaged (not completely passive) for safety.

name: Arm Circles
description: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and extend your arms straight out to the sides at shoulder height, palms facing down. Make small circular motions with your arms, gradually increasing the size of the circles. After 10-15 seconds, reverse the direction. Keep your core engaged and shoulders down - avoid shrugging. This simple movement warms up the shoulder joint and activates the deltoids. Can be performed with light weights for added resistance.

name: Arnold Press
description: Sit or stand holding dumbbells at shoulder height with palms facing your body (like the top of a bicep curl). As you press the weights overhead, rotate your palms to face forward by the time your arms are fully extended. Reverse the movement on the way down - rotate palms back toward you as you lower the weights to the starting position. This rotation works all three heads of the deltoid through a full range of motion. Named after Arnold Schwarzenegger who popularized this variation.

name: Arrow Push-ups
description: Start in push-up position. Lower your body while shifting to one side, extending that arm forward like an arrow. Push back up to center, then repeat on the other side. Alternate sides with each rep for balanced strength development.

name: Asian Squat
description: Lower into a deep squat with feet flat on the ground, heels down. Your hips should drop as low as possible while maintaining balance. Keep your torso upright and arms relaxed or out in front for balance. Hold this position. Excellent for ankle, hip, and lower back mobility. A fundamental resting position used throughout Asia.

name: Assisted Dip
description: Loop a resistance band between parallel bars and place your knees or feet in the loop. Perform dips with the band assisting you. Lower until shoulders are below elbows, then push back up to full arm extension.

name: Assisted Pull-up
description: Loop a resistance band over the pull-up bar and place one or both feet in the loop. Perform a full pull-up with the band assisting you. Focus on pulling your elbows down and back, getting chin over the bar. Lower with control.

name: Assisted Squat
description: Hold onto a sturdy object like a doorframe or pole. Perform a squat while using your arms to assist on the way up. Focus on sitting back into your heels and keeping your chest up. Use less assistance as you get stronger.

name: Back Extension
description: Lie face down on a back extension bench with hips on the pad and feet anchored. Cross arms over chest or behind head. Lower your upper body toward the floor, then raise back up until your body forms a straight line. Don't hyperextend.

name: Back Lever
description: A challenging gymnastics hold with your body horizontal and arms behind you. From German hang, lower your body with straight legs together until your back is parallel to the ground. Arms are straight behind you, body forms one rigid line. This places extreme demands on shoulder extension flexibility and strength, plus requires intense core tension. The biceps tendons are particularly stressed in this position. Prerequisites: comfortable German hang (30+ seconds), tuck back lever (15 seconds), straddle back lever (10+ seconds). Progress slowly - this movement can cause injury if rushed. Keep arms straight, body tight, and don't hold your breath. A 5-10 second hold with perfect form is impressive.

name: Stability Ball Lunge
description: Stand facing away from a stability ball. Place the top of one foot on the ball behind you, toes pointed down. The ball should be about a leg's length away. Keep your front foot firmly planted. Lower into a lunge by bending your front knee, allowing the ball to roll slightly as your back leg extends. Descend until your front thigh is parallel to the ground. Push through your front heel to stand. The ball challenges your balance and activates stabilizer muscles.

name: Banded Bicep Curl
description: Stand on the center of a resistance band with feet shoulder-width apart, holding the ends with palms facing forward. Curl your hands toward your shoulders, keeping your elbows pinned at your sides. Squeeze your biceps at the top, then lower with control. The band provides accommodating resistance - harder at the top where you're strongest.

name: Banded Calf Raises
description: Stand on a resistance band with the balls of your feet, holding the band handles at shoulder height or stepping on the band to create tension. Rise up onto your toes as high as possible, squeezing your calves at the top. Lower with control. The band adds progressive resistance throughout the movement. Best performed for high reps (50-100) to fully fatigue the calves.

name: Banded Front Raise
description: Stand on the center of a resistance band with feet shoulder-width apart, holding the ends with arms at your sides, palms facing back. Raise your arms straight out in front of you to shoulder height, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. Lower with control. The band provides progressive resistance throughout the movement. Great for high-rep shoulder conditioning and front deltoid development.

name: Banded Lateral Raise
description: Stand on the center of a resistance band with feet shoulder-width apart, holding the ends with arms at your sides. Raise your arms out to the sides until they reach shoulder height, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. Lower with control. The band provides progressive resistance, making the top of the movement most challenging. Great for high-rep shoulder conditioning.

name: Banded Nordic Curl
description: Kneel with feet anchored under something sturdy. Attach a resistance band overhead and hold it for assistance. Slowly lower your torso forward, resisting with your hamstrings. Use the band to help pull yourself back up.

name: Banded Pallof Hold
description: Attach a resistance band at chest height. Stand sideways to the anchor point. Press the band straight out in front of you and hold this position, resisting the rotational pull. Maintain a tight core and square hips throughout the hold.

name: Banded Push-up
description: Loop a resistance band across your upper back and hold the ends in each hand on the floor. Perform push-ups as normal - the band adds resistance at the top of the movement, making lockout harder. This builds explosive pushing power and helps progress toward more difficult push-up variations. Keep core tight throughout.

name: Banded Rear Delt Raise
description: Stand on the center of a resistance band with feet shoulder-width apart, holding the ends with arms hanging in front of you, palms facing back. With a slight bend in the elbows, raise your arms out to the sides and slightly back, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top. Lower with control. Excellent for posterior shoulder health and posture correction.

name: Banded Soleus Raises
description: Sit on a chair or bench with knees bent at 90 degrees. Place a resistance band over your knees and stand on the band with the balls of your feet. Raise your heels off the ground by pushing through your toes, lifting against the band resistance. Lower with control. The bent knee position targets the soleus muscle specifically, which is crucial for ankle stability and endurance activities like running.

name: Banded Squat (Behind Neck)
description: Stand on a resistance band with feet shoulder-width apart and loop the band behind your neck/over your shoulders (like a barbell back squat position). Perform squats as normal - the band adds resistance at the top of the movement, challenging your lockout. Keep chest up, core tight, and drive through your heels. Great for building explosive power out of the bottom position.

name: Bar Hand Switches
description: A wrist and hand mobility exercise for preparing the wrists for bar work. Stand or kneel with a bar (or use an imaginary bar position). Start with your hands in a standard grip position. Switch your hand position by rotating your wrists - alternate between overhand grip, underhand grip, and various angles. You can also perform wrist circles and rotations while maintaining the bar position. Focus on gradually increasing range of motion with each repetition. This exercise lubricates the wrist joints, improves flexibility, and prepares the wrists and forearms for gripping exercises like pull-ups, barbell squats, or bench presses. Perform slowly and stop if you feel any pain. Great for pre-workout wrist preparation.

name: Barbell Bent-Over Row
description: Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding the barbell with an overhand grip slightly wider than shoulders. Hinge at the hips until torso is roughly 45 degrees to the floor, keeping back flat and core braced. Row the bar toward your lower chest, driving elbows back past your torso. Squeeze shoulder blades at the top, then lower with control. Keep the bar path close to your legs throughout. This is a fundamental back builder.

name: Barbell Good Morning
description: Position barbell across upper back in squat position. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, soft bend in knees. Brace your core hard. Push hips back while keeping back flat and chest up, lowering torso until nearly parallel to floor. Feel the deep stretch in hamstrings. Squeeze glutes and drive hips forward to return. Start light—this movement requires excellent hip hinge mechanics before adding significant weight.

name: Barbell Romanian Deadlift
description: Stand holding a barbell at hip level with an overhand grip, feet hip-width apart. Push your hips back while keeping legs nearly straight (slight knee bend). Lower the bar along your legs until you feel a deep hamstring stretch - typically just below the knees. Keep your back flat and chest up throughout. Drive your hips forward to return to standing, squeezing glutes at the top. The bar stays close to your body the entire movement.

name: Barbell Shoulder Press
description: Stand with barbell at shoulder height, grip slightly wider than shoulders. Press the bar straight overhead until arms are fully extended. Lower back to shoulders with control. Keep core tight and avoid excessive arching. Also known as strict press or military press.

name: All Fours Side Kick
description: Start on all fours. Cross one knee behind the other, then kick that leg out to the side. (Day 8)

name: Attitude Position Kickback
description: On all fours, lift one leg with the knee bent and ankle crossed over/angled (attitude position). (Day 20)

name: Side-Lying Bent Leg Lift
description: Lie on side with legs bent at 90 degrees. Lift the entire top leg (knee and ankle) parallel to the floor. (Day 25)

name: Bridge with Single Leg Lift
description: Lie on back in bridge position. Lift one leg straight up to the ceiling while pulsing hips up and down. (Day 14)

media.caption: Bridge with Single Leg Lift illustration

name: Bridge with Tendu
description: Hold a glute bridge position. Extend one leg straight out forward (knees aligned) or point toe. (Day 29)

name: Clamshell
description: Lie on your side with legs stacked and knees bent. Keep feet touching while opening the top knee upward. (Day 3)

name: All Fours Donkey Kick
description: From all fours, extend one leg straight back and slightly up, engaging the glute. (Day 17)

name: Donkey Kick Pulse
description: On all fours, perform donkey kick pulses with the sole of the foot toward the ceiling. Use a weight behind the knee if possible. (Day 21)

name: Fire Hydrant
description: Start on all fours. Lift one bent knee out to the side (fire hydrant movement) keeping hips square. (Day 12)

name: First Position Plié
description: Stand with heels touching and toes out (first position). Rise onto toes, bend knees into a diamond shape, and pulse or straighten. (Day 5)

name: Glute Kickback
description: Start on all fours or elbows. Keep one knee bent and lift the leg up towards the ceiling, squeezing the glute at the top. (Day 1)

name: Grand Plié to Passé Rise
description: Perform a grande plié (deep squat), then rise and bring one foot to passé (knee bent, toe to knee). Alternate sides. (Day 15)

media.caption: Grand Plié to Passé Rise illustration

name: Leg Circle Series
description: Start on all fours. Extend one leg straight back. Tap the toe to the floor on the left, lift in a high arc, and tap on the right. (Day 6)

name: Plié Squat Jump
description: Perform explosive plié squat jumps, landing softly through the feet. (Day 22)

name: Plié to Relevé
description: Focus on external rotators. Perform a plié, rise to toes (relevé), and extend to straight legs. (Day 13)

name: Pretzel Leg Lift
description: Seated or side-lying pretzel position. Lift the back leg off the floor while keeping the torso upright. (Day 19)

name: Prone Glute Lift
description: Lie on stomach. Bend knees and bring heels together. Raise knees off the floor while keeping upper body static. (Day 16)

name: Barre Leg Pulses
description: Stand holding a barre. Lower into a small plié squat and perform continuous small pulses, keeping the torso upright and engaging glutes and quads throughout.

name: Relevé Passé
description: Stand on one leg with the other foot resting against the standing inner thigh (passé position). Rise up onto the ball of the standing foot (relevé) and lower. (Day 2)

name: Rond de Jambe
description: Stand at barre. Extend outside leg and perform small controlled circles (rond de jambe). (Day 30)

name: Scissor Kick
description: Lie on back, lift legs to 45 or 90 degrees. Criss-cross legs over one another (scissor kicks). (Day 28)

name: Side-Lying Leg Lift
description: Lie on your side, propped on one elbow. Extend the top leg straight out and lift/lower or circle it. (Day 9)

name: Single Leg Deadlift at Barre
description: Face a barre or chair. Hinge forward at hips, keeping back flat. Lift one leg straight back behind you. (Day 11)

media.caption: Single Leg Deadlift at Barre illustration

name: Squat Jump
description: Start in a narrow squat and jump out to a wide squat, or perform squat jumps. (Day 26)

name: Wide Plié Relevé Pulse
description: Stand in a wide plié position with feet wide and toes turned out. Rise up onto the balls of your feet (relevé) and pulse up and down while maintaining the wide stance. (Day 10)

name: Standing Abduction at Barre
description: Stand holding a barre. Lift outside leg straight out to the side. (Day 23)

name: Standing Arabesque Pulse
description: Hold onto a barre or chair. Lean forward slightly and extend one leg straight back, pulsing it upward. (Day 4)

name: Side-Lying Starfish Lift
description: Lie on side with legs extended straight. Lift both legs simultaneously like a starfish. (Day 24)

name: Superman Hold
description: Lie on stomach with arms and legs extended. Lift opposite arm and leg simultaneously. (Day 27)

name: Wide Plié Lift
description: Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width apart, toes pointed outward. Lower into a deep squat with knees bent and tracking over toes. Arms rounded in front of body at hip level in ballet first position (bras bas). Pulse up and down in small controlled movements.
imagePrompt: STANDING sumo squat position (NOT sitting, NOT on the ground): Person STANDING UPRIGHT on their feet with feet shoulder-width apart, toes turned out. KNEES BENT at 90 degrees like sitting in an invisible chair. Thighs parallel to ground. FEET FLAT ON GROUND. Arms rounded in front at waist level. This is a STANDING squat, NOT a split, NOT sitting on the floor.

name: Wide Plié Pulse
description: Stand with feet wide and toes turned out. Lower into a wide plié squat and perform small pulses. (Day 7)

name: Bear Crawl Hold
description: Start on all fours with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. Lift your knees 1-2 inches off the ground while keeping your back flat. Hold this position with core engaged. Your shins should be parallel to the floor. This isometric hold builds tremendous core stability.

name: Barbell Bench Press
description: Lie on a flat bench with feet on the floor. Lower the barbell to your chest, then press it back up to full arm extension.

name: Bicep Curl
description: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding dumbbells at your sides with palms facing forward. Curl the weights up by bending your elbows, keeping upper arms stationary. Squeeze biceps at the top, then lower with control.

name: Bicycle Crunches
description: Lie on back with hands behind head, legs raised. Bring right elbow to left knee while extending right leg, then switch sides in a pedaling motion. Keep lower back pressed to floor and avoid pulling on neck.

name: Bicycle Straight Legs
description: Lie on your back with hands behind head and both legs extended straight. Perform a bicycle motion but keep your legs straight as you bring each leg up. Twist your torso to bring opposite elbow toward the raised leg. This is more challenging than bent-leg bicycles due to the longer lever arm.

name: Bird Dog
description: Start on all fours with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. Brace your core and maintain a neutral spine. Slowly extend one arm forward and the opposite leg backward simultaneously, focusing on stability and control. Keep your core tight and back flat - don't let your hips rotate or twist. Hold the extended position for 2-3 seconds with maximum muscle activation, then return to starting position with control. Switch sides. Focus on quality over speed - each rep should be deliberate and controlled with full body tension. Part of Dr. Stuart McGill's Big 3 core stability exercises.

name: Boat Pose
description: Sit with knees bent, feet flat. Lean back slightly, lift feet off floor and extend legs to 45 degrees. Reach arms forward parallel to floor. Balance on sit bones, keeping spine straight and chest lifted. Hold and breathe.

name: Boat Pose Pulses
description: Hold boat pose with legs at 45 degrees and arms parallel to floor. While maintaining the V-shape, make small pulsing movements - slightly lowering and lifting your legs and torso. Keep the micro-movements controlled, never fully releasing the core tension. These pulses intensify the boat pose while building endurance in the elevated position.

name: Bodyweight Squat
description: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Bend knees and push hips back to lower into a squat. Go as deep as comfortable while keeping heels on ground and chest up. Stand back up by driving through your heels.

name: Box Jumps
description: Stand facing a box or platform. Jump explosively onto the box, landing softly with knees bent. Step back down and repeat.

name: Bridge Lift
description: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift hips up to form a bridge position, holding the top position. Raise one leg straight up while maintaining the bridge, then lower it and switch sides. Keep hips level throughout.

name: Bulgarian Split Squat
description: Stand on one leg with the rear foot elevated on a bench or chair behind you. Lower into a single-leg squat on the front leg until the rear knee nearly touches the ground. Push through the front heel to return to standing. Add weight by holding dumbbells at sides, a kettlebell at chest, a barbell across back, or use a Smith machine for guided stability.

name: Burpee
description: Start standing, then squat down and place hands on floor. Jump feet back to plank position, perform a push-up (optional), jump feet forward to hands, then explosively jump up with arms overhead. Land softly and repeat.

name: Butt Kicks
description: Run in place while kicking your heels up toward your glutes with each step. Pump your arms in a running motion. Keep a quick pace and try to actually touch your heels to your butt with each kick. Stay light on your feet with minimal ground contact time.

name: Butterfly Stretch
description: Sit on the floor and bring the soles of your feet together, letting your knees fall out to the sides. Hold your feet with your hands and gently press your knees toward the floor with your elbows. For a deeper stretch, lean forward from your hips. This opens the hips and stretches the inner thighs.

name: Cable Bicep Curl
description: Stand facing the low cable with a straight bar or EZ-bar attachment. Grip the handle with palms up, arms extended, elbows at your sides. Curl the bar up toward your shoulders, keeping elbows stationary. Squeeze biceps at the top, then lower with control. The constant cable tension makes this excellent for muscle building.

name: Cable Chest Fly
description: Set cable pulleys to shoulder height. Stand in the center with a handle in each hand, arms extended out to the sides with a slight elbow bend. Step forward into a staggered stance for stability. Bring your hands together in front of your chest in a hugging motion, squeezing your pecs hard at the center. Control the weight back, feeling the stretch in your chest. Keep the same elbow angle throughout - this is a fly, not a press.

name: Cable Lateral Raise
description: Stand sideways to a low cable pulley with the handle in your far hand (cable crosses in front of your body). Keep a slight bend in your elbow and raise your arm out to the side until it reaches shoulder height. Lower with control. The cable provides constant tension throughout the range of motion, unlike dumbbells which are hardest at the top. Complete all reps then switch sides.

name: Cable Row Machine
description: Sit at the cable row machine with your feet secured on the platform. Adjust the seat height so the handle is at chest level when your arms are extended. Grip the handle with both hands, palms facing each other. Pull the handle toward your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement. Keep your core engaged and avoid arching your back. Slowly return to the starting position with control.

name: Cable Tricep Pushdown
description: Stand facing the cable machine with a straight bar or rope attachment at face height. Grip the handle with arms bent at 90 degrees, elbows pinned to your sides. Push the handle down until arms are straight, squeezing triceps at the bottom. Control the weight back up without letting your elbows drift forward. Keep your core tight and avoid leaning into the movement.

name: Seated Calf Raise Machine
description: Sit in the machine with the pads resting on your lower thighs and balls of feet on the platform. Lower your heels below the platform for a full stretch. Press through the balls of your feet to raise your heels as high as possible, squeezing calves at the top. Lower with control for a full stretch. The seated position targets the soleus muscle specifically.

name: Candlestick
description: Lie on your back with arms along your sides, palms down. Using your core, lift your legs and hips off the floor, rolling up onto your shoulders until your legs point straight toward the ceiling. Your weight rests on your upper back and shoulders. Hold briefly at the top, then roll back down with control. This is a dynamic core exercise that also builds body awareness and control.

name: Cat-Cow Stretch
description: Start on hands and knees. For Cow: inhale, drop belly, lift chest and tailbone, look up. For Cat: exhale, round spine toward ceiling, tuck chin to chest. Flow between positions with each breath to mobilize the spine.

name: Chair Dip
description: Sit on the edge of a sturdy chair and place your hands on the edge beside your hips. Slide your hips off the chair with legs extended or bent (easier). Lower your body by bending your elbows until they reach about 90 degrees. Push back up to the starting position. Great bodyweight tricep exercise that can be done anywhere with a chair or bench.

name: Chest Press Machine
description: Adjust seat height so handles are at mid-chest level. Sit with back flat against pad and feet on floor. Grip handles and press forward, extending arms without locking elbows. Squeeze chest at full extension, then control the weight back. The machine guides your movement path, making this ideal for learning pressing patterns.

name: Child's Pose
description: Kneel on floor, sit back on heels, then fold forward with arms extended in front or alongside body. Rest forehead on mat. Breathe deeply into your back and hips. A restorative pose for recovery between exercises.

name: Chin-up
description: A pull-up variation with palms facing toward you (supinated grip). Hang from a bar with hands shoulder-width apart, palms facing you. Pull yourself up until your chin clears the bar, focusing on driving your elbows down. Lower with control to full extension. The supinated grip increases bicep involvement compared to standard pull-ups, often making chin-ups easier for beginners. Keep your core tight and avoid excessive swinging. This is an excellent pulling exercise and a great way to build toward standard pull-ups.

name: Clap Jack
description: A jumping jack variation with an overhead clap. Start with feet together and arms at sides. Jump feet apart while swinging arms overhead and clapping at the top. Jump back to starting position with arms returning to sides. The clap adds coordination and engages the shoulders more than standard jumping jacks. Keep a steady rhythm and land softly on the balls of your feet.

name: Close Grip Cable Row
description: Sit at the cable row machine with a close grip handle attachment. Secure your feet on the platform and extend your arms fully. Grip the handle with hands close together, palms facing each other. Pull the handle toward your lower chest/upper abdomen, keeping your elbows close to your body. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement. This close grip emphasizes the middle traps and rhomboids.

name: Close Grip Push-up
description: Perform a push-up with hands placed close together, directly under your chest. This variation increases triceps engagement compared to standard push-ups.

name: Commando Pull-up
description: A pull-up variation performed with hands in line (one in front of the other) along the bar. Stand perpendicular to the bar and grip it with one hand in front of the other, palms facing each other. Pull up, bringing your head to one side of the bar. Lower and repeat, alternating which side of the bar your head goes to. This grip variation hits your muscles differently, adding rotational core work and grip challenge. Also called a typewriter pull-up or commando grip pull-up.

name: Concentration Curl
description: Sit on a bench with legs spread. Hold a dumbbell in one hand and brace your elbow against the inside of your thigh. Curl the weight up toward your shoulder, focusing on squeezing the bicep at the top. Lower with control. Complete all reps on one side before switching.

name: Copenhagen Plank
description: Set up in a side plank position with your top leg resting on an elevated surface (bench or box). Your bottom leg hangs free. Lift your hips to create a straight line from head to top foot. Hold this position. The adductor engagement adds significant challenge to standard side plank.

name: Cossack Squat
description: Stand with feet wide apart (about double shoulder width). Shift your weight to one side, bending that knee deeply while keeping the other leg completely straight with toes pointing up. Descend as low as possible on the bent leg - ideally hamstring touches calf. Keep your heel down and chest up. The straight leg stretches the adductors. Rise and repeat on the other side. Use a yoga block under your heel if ankle mobility is limited. Also known as Russian squat.

name: Couch Stretch
description: Face away from a wall or couch. Place one knee on the ground and your shin/foot up against the wall. Step the other foot forward into a lunge. Push your hips forward and keep your torso upright. This intensely stretches the hip flexors and quads of the back leg. Known as one of the most effective hip flexor stretches.

name: Crab March
description: A challenging locomotion exercise in crab position. Sit on the floor and place your hands behind you, fingers pointing toward your feet. Lift your hips off the ground so your body forms a tabletop position - this is crab position. March forward by moving opposite hand and foot together (right hand + left foot, then left hand + right foot). Keep your hips lifted and core engaged throughout. You can also march backward or side to side. This builds shoulder stability, tricep strength, and full-body coordination while keeping heart rate elevated.

name: Cross-Body Mountain Climbers
description: Start in high plank position. Bring right knee toward left shoulder, return to plank, then bring left knee toward right shoulder. Move explosively while maintaining a strong plank position. This variation targets obliques more than standard climbers.

name: Cross Crunch Toe Tap
description: An alternating cross-body crunch with a toe tap. Lie on your back with legs extended and arms reaching overhead. Lift your right leg and reach your left hand across your body to tap the outside of your right foot, crunching your obliques. Lower back down with control, then repeat on the opposite side - left leg up, right hand reaches to tap. Keep your lower back pressed into the floor and exhale as you crunch up. This targets the obliques and hip flexors while adding coordination.

name: Crow Pose
description: Squat down and place your hands flat on the floor shoulder-width apart. Place your knees on the backs of your upper arms/triceps. Lean forward, shifting weight into your hands, and lift your feet off the ground. Balance with arms bent and core engaged. This pose builds arm strength, core stability, and hip flexibility.

name: Crow Push-up
description: From crow pose position (knees resting on triceps, balanced on hands), lower your head toward the floor by bending your elbows, then press back up to crow pose. This is extremely challenging and requires significant upper body strength and balance. Keep your core tight and gaze forward throughout. A prerequisite for planche training.

name: Crow to Plank
description: Start in crow pose with knees on triceps. With control, extend your legs back to plank position while keeping your hands planted. Then jump or step your knees back to your triceps to return to crow pose. This transitions between two fundamental positions and builds the control needed for more advanced skill work. Focus on smooth, controlled movement rather than speed.

name: Crunch
description: Lie on your back with knees bent, feet flat on the floor. Place hands gently behind your head (don't pull on neck). Engage your core and lift your shoulders off the ground by curling your chest toward your knees. Lower back down with control.

name: Curl to Press
description: Stand with dumbbells at your sides. Perform a bicep curl, bringing weights to shoulder height. From there, rotate your wrists so palms face forward and press the weights overhead. Reverse the movement to return to starting position. This combines bicep curls and shoulder presses into one fluid movement.

name: Curtsy Lunge
description: Stand with feet hip-width apart and hands on your hips or at your chest. Step your right foot diagonally behind your left leg, crossing it behind as you lower into a lunge position - like a curtsy. Keep your front knee tracking over your toes and your torso upright. Lower until your front thigh is nearly parallel to the ground. Push through your front heel to return to standing. This variation targets the outer glutes (gluteus medius) more than standard lunges.

name: Dead Bug
description: Lie on your back with arms extended toward ceiling and knees bent at 90 degrees. Slowly lower opposite arm and leg toward the floor while keeping your lower back pressed into the ground. Return and repeat on the other side.

name: Dead Bug (Arms and Legs)
description: Lie on your back with arms extended toward the ceiling and knees bent at 90 degrees, shins parallel to the floor. Simultaneously lower your opposite arm overhead and opposite leg toward the floor while keeping your lower back pressed firmly into the ground. Return to start and repeat on the other side. Full range variation that challenges anti-extension and core stability.

name: Dead Bug Opposite Reach
description: Lie on your back with arms extended toward ceiling and knees at 90 degrees. Slowly extend one arm overhead toward the floor while simultaneously extending the opposite leg straight out. Keep your lower back pressed into the ground throughout. Return to start and alternate sides.

name: Dead Hang
description: Simply hanging from a bar with arms fully extended - the foundation of all bar work. Grab a pull-up bar with an overhand grip and let your body hang with arms straight. Relax your shoulders initially (passive hang), then practice engaging them by pulling your shoulder blades down and back (active hang). Both variations have benefits: passive hangs decompress the spine and stretch the shoulders; active hangs build scapular control. Build up your hang time - this develops grip strength, shoulder health, and comfort on the bar. Aim for 30-60 second holds. This is prerequisite for all pull-up progressions.

name: Conventional Deadlift
description: Stand with feet hip-width apart, barbell over midfoot. Hinge at hips, grip the bar, and stand up by extending hips and knees simultaneously.

name: Smith Machine Deadlift
description: Position yourself in the Smith machine with the bar over your midfoot. Stand with feet hip-width apart, hinge at the hips to grip the bar just outside your legs. Keep your chest up and back flat. Drive through your heels, extending your hips and knees simultaneously to stand tall. Reverse the movement with control, pushing your hips back while keeping the bar close to your body. The guided bar path allows you to focus on form.

name: Decline Push-up
description: Perform a push-up with your feet elevated on a bench or step. This increases the load on your upper chest and shoulders compared to standard push-ups.

name: Diamond Push-ups
description: Place hands together under your chest, forming a diamond shape with thumbs and index fingers. Lower your chest toward your hands, keeping elbows close to body. Push back up. This variation emphasizes triceps activation.

name: Diaphragmatic Breathing (Deep Core Activation)
description: This is the foundation of deep core activation. Lie on your back with knees bent, feet flat on floor hip-width apart. Place one hand on your chest and one on your belly just below your ribcage. INHALE slowly through your nose for 4 counts, feeling your belly rise into your hand while your chest stays relatively still - this is your diaphragm descending. EXHALE slowly through pursed lips for 6-8 counts, feeling your belly fall as your deep core muscles (transverse abdominis) engage to push air out. On the exhale, imagine you're gently drawing your belly button toward your spine and 'zipping up' from your pubic bone to your navel. This activates your deep stabilizing muscles including the pelvic floor. Each breath cycle is one rep. Stay relaxed in your shoulders and neck - all the action is in your core.

name: Dip
description: Support yourself on parallel bars with arms straight. Lower your body by bending your elbows until shoulders are below elbows. Keep core tight and lean slightly forward for chest emphasis. Push back up to full arm extension.

name: Donkey Kick to Handstand
description: A two-footed kick up to handstand that builds explosive power for handstand entries. Start standing facing away from a wall (about 2-3 feet away). Place hands on the ground shoulder-width apart. With a slight jump, kick both feet up simultaneously toward the wall in a 'donkey kick' motion. The goal is to land with both feet on the wall in a back-to-wall handstand position. This teaches the hip drive and shoulder positioning needed for freestanding handstand kick-ups. Start with small kicks, gradually increasing height as you build confidence. Focus on keeping arms straight and shoulders open throughout the kick.

name: Double Kettlebell Clean
description: Start with two kettlebells on the floor between your feet. Hinge and grip both handles, then in one explosive motion pull the bells up close to your body and rotate your hands underneath to catch them in the rack position at your chest. Elbows stay tucked, bells rest on the forearms. Reverse the motion to return to the start. Requires solid single-bell clean technique before attempting doubles.

name: Double Kettlebell Snatch
description: The most demanding double kettlebell movement. From the floor or swing position, explosively pull both bells overhead in one continuous motion, punching through at the top to lockout with arms straight. Requires tremendous grip, shoulder stability, and explosive hip power. Master single-bell snatches and double cleans before attempting. Keep core and glutes tight throughout.

name: Double Kettlebell Swing
description: Same as a standard kettlebell swing but with two bells. Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width, a kettlebell in each hand on the floor between your feet. Hike both bells back, then explosively snap hips forward to swing them to chest height. The doubled load demands significantly more grip strength, core stability, and hip power. Keep arms straight and let the hips do the work.

name: Down Dog Knee to Head
description: Start in downward dog position. Drive one knee under your body toward your head, tapping the top of your head with your knee, then extend the leg back to starting position. Alternate legs in a controlled, flowing motion.

name: Down Dog Leg Raise
description: Start in downward dog position with hands and feet shoulder-width apart. Raise one leg up behind you, driving the knee toward your chest, then extend it back up. Return to starting position and switch legs. Keep hips level throughout.

name: Downward Dog
description: Start on hands and knees. Lift hips up and back, forming an inverted V-shape. Press heels toward the floor and straighten legs.

name: Dumbbell Chest Fly
description: Lie on a flat bench holding dumbbells above your chest with arms nearly straight and palms facing each other. Lower the weights out to your sides in a wide arc until you feel a stretch in your chest. Bring the weights back together above your chest, squeezing your pecs.

name: Dumbbell Goblet Squat
description: Hold a dumbbell vertically against your chest, cupping the top end with both hands. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Squat down keeping chest up and elbows inside your knees. Go as deep as mobility allows. Drive through heels to stand. The front load forces great posture.

name: Dumbbell Tricep Kickback
description: Hinge forward at hips with flat back. Hold dumbbells with elbows bent at 90 degrees, tucked to your sides. Extend arms straight back, squeezing triceps at the top. Lower with control. Keep upper arms stationary - only your forearms move. Can do one arm at a time using other hand for support.

name: Dumbbell Walking Lunge
description: Hold dumbbells at your sides. Step forward into a lunge, lowering until both knees are at 90 degrees. Front knee stays over ankle. Drive through front heel to step forward into the next lunge on the opposite leg. Keep torso upright throughout. For stationary lunges, return to start between reps.

name: Dumbbell Pullover
description: Lie perpendicular across a bench with just your upper back on the bench. Hold one dumbbell with both hands above your chest. With slight elbow bend, lower dumbbell behind your head in an arc until you feel a stretch. Pull back up in the same arc. Keep hips up and core braced.

name: Dumbbell Reverse Fly
description: Hinge forward at hips with flat back, arms hanging straight down holding dumbbells. With slight bend in elbows, raise arms out to sides until they're parallel to floor. Squeeze shoulder blades together at top. Lower with control. Keep torso stable - don't swing.

name: Dumbbell Romanian Deadlift
description: Stand holding dumbbells in front of thighs. Push hips back while keeping legs nearly straight (soft knee bend). Lower dumbbells along your legs until you feel a deep hamstring stretch. Keep back flat. Drive hips forward to stand. Dumbbells stay close to body throughout the movement.

name: Dumbbell Row
description: Place one knee and hand on a bench for support. Hold dumbbell in the other hand with arm hanging straight down. Pull dumbbell to your hip, squeezing shoulder blade back. Lower with control. Keep back flat and core braced. Don't rotate torso. Complete all reps then switch sides.

name: Dumbbell Shoulder Press
description: Sit or stand with dumbbells held at shoulder height, palms facing forward. Press the weights overhead until arms are fully extended. Lower back to shoulder height with control. Keep core tight and avoid arching your back.

name: Dumbbell Shrug
description: Stand holding dumbbells at your sides with arms straight. Shrug shoulders straight up toward your ears as high as possible. Squeeze at the top for a moment. Lower with control. Don't roll shoulders - straight up and down only. Keep arms straight throughout.

name: Dumbbell Skull Crusher
description: Lie on a bench holding dumbbells with arms extended above your chest. Keep upper arms stationary. Bend elbows to lower dumbbells toward your forehead (hence 'skull crusher'). Extend elbows to return to start. Keep wrists neutral throughout. Can also be done on floor.

name: Egg Push-ups
description: Perform a push-up with your elbows tucked closely to your body, creating an egg-shaped form. This variation increases triceps engagement compared to standard push-ups.

name: Elevated Pike Push-up
description: Set up in pike push-up position but with your feet elevated on a box, bench, or step. The higher your feet, the more vertical and challenging the movement becomes. Lower your head toward the floor between your hands, then press back up. This is a key progression toward handstand push-ups, shifting more weight onto your shoulders. Keep core tight throughout.

name: Elevated Push-ups
description: Place your feet on a raised surface (bench, step, or box) with hands on the floor. Maintain a straight line from head to heels. Lower chest toward the floor, then push back up. The elevation shifts emphasis to upper chest and shoulders.

name: Extended Side Angle (Utthita Parsvakonasana)
description: From Warrior II, lower your front forearm to rest on your front thigh (or place hand on floor inside front foot for deeper stretch). Extend your top arm overhead, creating a line from back foot to fingertips. Open chest toward ceiling. Hold and breathe deeply, then switch sides.

name: False Grip to Dip Transition
description: A muscle-up transition drill practicing the movement from false grip pull to support/dip position. Start hanging from rings with a false grip (wrists wrapped over the rings, not palms). Pull yourself up as if doing a pull-up. As your chest reaches ring height, lean forward aggressively, rolling your hands over the rings and transitioning into the bottom of a dip position. Press up to support hold. Lower back down with control. This is the transition portion of a muscle-up, isolated for practice. Focus on the aggressive forward lean and fast hand rotation. The false grip must be maintained throughout the pull to make the transition possible. Prerequisite for ring muscle-ups.

name: Feet Elevated Push-up
description: Place your feet on an elevated surface like a chair, box, or bench. Get into push-up position with hands on the floor. Perform push-ups with feet elevated, which increases the difficulty and emphasizes the upper chest and shoulders. Keep your body in a hollow body position with core tight throughout the movement.

name: Figure Four Stretch
description: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat. Cross one ankle over the opposite knee, creating a figure-4 shape. Thread your hands through the gap and pull the bottom leg toward your chest. Hold for 30 seconds, feeling the stretch in your hip and glute. Switch sides. Excellent for hip mobility and glute flexibility.

name: Flutter Kicks
description: Lie on your back with legs extended. Lift shoulders slightly off the ground. Rapidly alternate kicking your legs up and down in a fluttering motion without touching the ground.

name: Forearm Stand
description: An inverted balance hold on your forearms - also known as Pincha Mayurasana in yoga. Start in dolphin pose (forearm plank with hips piked up). Place forearms parallel on the floor, shoulder-width apart, with palms flat or fingers interlaced. Walk your feet toward your elbows to stack hips over shoulders. Kick one leg up (or press both legs up for advanced practitioners) into the inverted position. Balance with legs together, pointed toward the ceiling, body in a straight line. Keep your core engaged, press firmly through your forearms, and look between your hands. Practice against a wall first before attempting freestanding. This builds shoulder strength and body awareness for handstand progression.

name: Frog Stretch
description: Start on all fours with knees wider than hip-width. Turn your feet out so the inner edges are on the ground. Slowly widen your knees and sink your hips back, lowering onto your forearms if comfortable. You should feel a deep stretch in your inner thighs and hips. This is an intense hip opener.

name: Frogger
description: Start in a high plank position with hands under shoulders. Jump both feet forward to the outside of your hands, landing in a deep squat position. Jump feet back to plank position. Keep your core engaged throughout and maintain a quick rhythm. This is like a burpee without the jump or push-up.

name: Front Lever
description: One of the most impressive calisthenics holds - your body held horizontally with arms straight. From a dead hang, engage your entire posterior chain and pull your body up and back until you're completely horizontal. Arms are straight, body forms one rigid line from hands to toes, legs straight and together. This requires extraordinary lat strength, core tension, and total body control. The pulling force comes primarily from your lats - think about pulling the bar toward your hips. Common mistakes: bent arms, piked hips, sagging body. Master all progressions first: tuck (10-15s), advanced tuck (10-15s), straddle (10-15s). Achieving even a 5-second hold with perfect form is a significant accomplishment.

name: Front Lever Pull
description: A dynamic front lever movement - essentially a pull-up performed in the front lever position. Start in your front lever hold (tuck, straddle, or full depending on ability). From this horizontal position, pull yourself up toward the bar while maintaining your body's horizontal orientation. Lower back to the front lever position with control. This is significantly harder than a standard pull-up because of the mechanical disadvantage and the need to maintain core tension throughout. Even performing tuck front lever pulls builds incredible strength. Focus on quality over quantity - a few good reps trump sloppy high reps.

name: Front Raise
description: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding dumbbells in front of your thighs with palms facing down. Raise the weights straight out in front of you to shoulder height, keeping arms nearly straight. Lower with control. Focus on using your front deltoids.

name: Full Body Toe Tap
description: Start lying flat with arms extended overhead and legs straight on the floor. Simultaneously lift your arms and one leg, reaching to tap your toe at the top. Lower everything back to start position, then repeat with the opposite leg. Full range of motion from fully extended to toe tap.

name: Full Planche
description: The ultimate horizontal pushing hold - body parallel to the ground supported only by straight arms with legs together. This is one of the hardest calisthenics skills to achieve. From floor or parallettes, lean forward with locked arms until your body lifts into a perfectly horizontal position. Legs are straight and together. Shoulders protracted, entire body rigid. The strength demands on your anterior deltoids, chest, and core are extreme. Most athletes require years of dedicated training to achieve this. Prerequisites: straddle planche (10+ seconds), exceptional pushing strength, conditioned wrists, and patience. Don't rush this progression - proper development prevents shoulder injuries. Even a 2-3 second hold is world-class.

name: German Hang
description: An inverted hang position with arms behind the body, stretching the shoulders into deep extension. From a dead hang, perform a skin the cat movement to rotate backwards until your arms are behind you and your body hangs inverted. Hold this position with straight arms. You should feel an intense stretch in your chest, biceps, and front shoulders. This position builds the shoulder extension flexibility essential for back levers, planche, and advanced ring work. Start with bent knees to reduce intensity, and only go as deep as your shoulders comfortably allow. Progress slowly - forcing this position can cause injury. Hold for 15-30 seconds, building up over time.

name: Glute Bridge
description: Lie on back with knees bent, feet flat on floor hip-width apart. Drive through heels to lift hips toward ceiling, squeezing glutes at the top. Lower with control. Keep core engaged and avoid overarching lower back.

name: GMB Wrist Prep
description: A comprehensive wrist warmup routine including: Finger pulses, palm pulses, side-to-side palm rotations, front-facing elbow rotations, side-to-side wrist stretch, rear-facing wrist stretch (palms down), rear-facing wrist stretch (palms up), rear-facing elbow rotations, and forward-facing wrist stretch. Do as many reps as needed.

name: Good Morning
description: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hands behind your head or crossed on chest. Keep your back straight and knees slightly bent. Hinge at the hips, pushing them back and lowering your torso until it's nearly parallel to the floor. Feel the stretch in your hamstrings. Return to standing by squeezing your glutes and driving your hips forward. Progress with a dumbbell held at chest, barbell across back, or Smith machine for guided resistance.

name: Gorilla Row
description: Place two kettlebells or dumbbells on the floor about shoulder-width apart. Stand over them with feet slightly wider than the weights. Hinge at the hips with a flat back to grip both weights. Row one weight up to your hip while pressing the other into the floor for stability. Lower with control and immediately row the other side. This alternating pattern challenges your core to resist rotation while building back strength. Keep your hips square and avoid twisting your torso.

name: Hack Squat
description: Position yourself in the hack squat machine with your back against the pad and shoulders under the pads. Place feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. Release the safety handles and lower your body by bending your knees until thighs are parallel to the platform. Keep your back pressed against the pad throughout. Drive through your heels to extend your legs and return to standing. The machine provides support while allowing heavy loading of the quads.

name: Hammer Curl
description: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding dumbbells at your sides with palms facing each other (neutral grip). Curl the weights up while maintaining the neutral grip. This variation targets the brachialis and forearms more than standard curls.

name: Handstand Box Hold
description: A handstand entry position using a box to build shoulder strength and body position awareness. Place hands on the floor shoulder-width apart, about 1-2 feet from a sturdy box or elevated surface. Place your feet on the box with knees bent. Walk your hands back toward the box while straightening your legs, until your hips stack over your shoulders and your body forms an L-shape (or closer to inverted as you progress). Hold this position with arms straight, actively pushing through your shoulders, and core engaged. This teaches proper handstand alignment - shoulders over wrists, hollow body position - without the full balance challenge. Progress by walking hands closer to the box for a more vertical position.

name: Handstand Kick-up
description: The standard single-leg kick-up entry into a handstand. Start in a lunge position with hands on the floor shoulder-width apart, front leg bent, back leg straight. Shift weight onto your hands while kicking your back leg up powerfully toward the ceiling. As the back leg rises, push off with your front foot to bring both legs together overhead. For wall-assisted practice, kick up to a back-to-wall handstand first. The key is leading with your hips - think of stacking your hips over your shoulders first, then bringing the legs together. Keep arms straight and actively push through your shoulders. Practice controlled kick-ups before attempting freestanding holds.

name: Handstand Wall Walk
description: Walk up to a wall-supported handstand to build strength and body awareness. Start in a push-up position with your feet against a wall. Walk your feet up the wall while simultaneously walking your hands backward toward the wall. Continue until your chest faces the wall and you are in a full handstand position with hands about 6-12 inches from the wall. Hold briefly at the top, then reverse the movement - walk hands away from the wall while walking feet down. Keep your core tight and arms straight throughout. This is chest-to-wall handstand practice, which promotes better alignment than back-to-wall. Control is key - don't rush the movement.

name: Hanging Knee Raise
description: A beginner-friendly hanging core exercise. Hang from a pull-up bar with arms extended. Engage your core and raise your knees toward your chest by curling your pelvis up. Lower with control without swinging. Keep the movement controlled - avoid using momentum. Exhale as you lift your knees. This builds the core strength and hip flexor endurance needed for hanging leg raises and more advanced hanging movements. It also develops grip strength and comfort hanging from a bar. Progression: start with small knee raises, work toward bringing knees to chest, then progress to straight-leg hanging leg raises.

name: Hanging Leg Raise
description: A challenging core exercise performed hanging from a pull-up bar. Hang from a bar with arms fully extended and shoulders engaged (not passive hanging). Keep your legs straight and together. Using your core and hip flexors, raise your legs until they are parallel to the ground (L-position) or higher. Lower with control without swinging. Avoid using momentum - the movement should be slow and controlled. If full leg raises are too difficult, start with knee raises (bending knees to chest) and progress to straight leg raises. This exercise builds serious core strength and hip flexor power, essential for L-sits, front levers, and toes-to-bar.

name: Happy Baby
description: Lie on your back and bring your knees toward your armpits. Grab the outside edges of your feet with your hands (or use a strap). Gently pull your knees down toward the floor while keeping your tailbone grounded. Rock gently side to side if desired. This deeply stretches the hips and inner thighs.

name: Headstand to Push-up
description: From headstand position, lower your legs down through a pike position and transition smoothly into a push-up at the bottom. Press back up and return to headstand. This flowing movement combines inversion work with pushing strength and requires excellent body control throughout the transition. Keep the movement smooth and controlled rather than using momentum.

name: Headstand Tuck Hold
description: From headstand position, bring your knees into your chest in a tucked position and hold. This challenges core stability and balance in the inverted position. Keep your elbows bent at 90 degrees with hands on the floor forming a tripod base. The tuck position is a progression toward freestanding headstand control and press to handstand.

name: High Knees
description: Run in place, driving your knees up toward your chest as high as possible with each step. Pump your arms in rhythm.

name: Hip Abductor Machine
description: Sit in the machine with outer thighs against the pads and feet on the foot rests. Push your legs outward against the resistance, focusing on squeezing your outer glutes. Control the movement back to the starting position - don't let the weight snap back. Great for targeting the gluteus medius and improving hip stability.

name: Hip Adductor Machine
description: Sit in the machine with inner thighs against the pads, legs spread to the starting position. Squeeze your legs together against the resistance, focusing on inner thigh activation. Control the movement back out - this eccentric phase is key. Strengthens the adductors for better hip stability and injury prevention.

name: Hip Flexor Lunge Stretch
description: Kneel on one knee with the other foot forward in a lunge position. Push your hips forward while keeping your torso upright until you feel a stretch in the front of your back hip. Hold for 30 seconds, then switch sides. For a deeper stretch, reach your arms overhead. Essential for counteracting sitting and tight hip flexors.

name: Hip Lift to Shoulder Stand
description: Lie on your back with legs extended. Lift your legs toward the ceiling, then use your core to lift your hips off the floor, pressing your legs straight up into a brief shoulder stand position. Lower your hips back down with control, then lower your legs. Each rep involves lifting up to the shoulder stand and returning. A dynamic core exercise that builds strength for full shoulder stands.

name: Hollow Body Hold
description: Lie on your back with arms extended overhead and legs straight. Lift shoulders and legs off the ground, creating a banana shape with your body. Hold this position while keeping lower back pressed into the floor.

name: Hollow Body Rocks
description: Start in a hollow body position - lying on back with arms overhead, shoulders and legs lifted, lower back pressed into floor. Maintain this banana shape and rock forward and backward using your core, not momentum. Keep the hollow position locked in throughout the rocking motion. This builds the dynamic core control essential for dance and gymnastics.

name: Hollow Hold Push-up
description: Perform push-ups while maintaining a hollow body position throughout. This means posteriorly tilting your pelvis (tucking tailbone), engaging your abs hard, and keeping your body in a slight banana curve rather than a straight line. Your lower back should never arch. This is significantly harder than regular push-ups and builds the core strength needed for advanced gymnastics skills.

name: Horizontal Row
description: Set up a bar or rings at hip height. Hang underneath with body horizontal and feet elevated on a box. Pull your chest to the bar, keeping body straight throughout. Squeeze shoulder blades at the top. Lower with control.

name: Ice Cream Maker
description: A dynamic front lever progression that moves between inverted hang and front lever. Start by pulling up into an inverted hang (body vertical, upside down). With straight arms, lower your body toward horizontal (front lever position), pause, then pull back up to inverted. The 'ice cream maker' name comes from the churning motion. This builds the specific lat and core strength for front levers through a full range of motion. Use your progression level: tuck, advanced tuck, or straddle. Focus on controlled movement - no swinging. This exercise develops strength through the entire range that a static hold cannot.

name: Inchworm Walkout
description: A dynamic full-body movement that stretches and strengthens. Stand tall with feet hip-width apart. Hinge at the hips and place your hands on the floor in front of your feet, keeping legs as straight as possible to stretch the hamstrings. Walk your hands forward one at a time until you reach a high plank position. Pause briefly in plank, then walk your feet forward in small steps toward your hands, keeping legs straight. Return to standing and repeat. This warms up the entire posterior chain, core, and shoulders while building shoulder stability.

name: Incline Dumbbell Fly
description: Lie on an incline bench (30-45 degrees) holding dumbbells above your chest with arms nearly straight and palms facing each other. Lower the weights out to your sides in a wide arc. Bring them back together above your chest. Targets the upper chest.

name: Incline Dumbbell Press
description: Lie on an incline bench (30-45 degrees) holding dumbbells at chest level. Press the weights up and slightly together until arms are extended. Lower with control back to chest level. This variation emphasizes the upper chest and front deltoids.

name: Incline Push-up
description: Place hands on an elevated surface like a bench, box, or sturdy chair. Perform a push-up by lowering your chest to the surface and pushing back up. Keep body straight from head to heels. Lower the surface height as you progress.

name: Incline Row
description: Set up a bar or rings at waist to chest height. Hang underneath with feet on ground, body straight. Pull your chest to the bar/rings, squeezing shoulder blades together. Lower with control. Adjust angle for difficulty.

name: Inverted Hang
description: Hanging upside down from a bar or rings with your body vertical. From a dead hang, pull your legs up and over, rotating until your body is inverted - head down, feet pointing up. Arms are straight and body is vertical. On a bar, you can hook your legs over for security while learning. On rings, you need to maintain the position through core tension. This builds comfort being inverted, core strength, and grip endurance. It's also the starting position for skin the cat, ice cream makers, and lever progressions. Start with short holds and progress gradually. Blood rushing to your head is normal - come down if you feel dizzy.

name: Jackknife Sits
description: Lie on your back with legs extended and arms extended overhead. In one movement, bring your torso and legs up together to meet in the middle, creating a V-shape. Lower back down and repeat. Move with control and precision.

name: Jump Lunge
description: Start in a lunge position with one foot forward, both knees bent at 90 degrees. Explosively jump up, switching legs mid-air so you land with the opposite foot forward. Land softly and immediately lower into the next lunge. Keep your torso upright and arms pumping for momentum.

name: Jump Rope
description: Hold the rope handles at hip height with elbows close to your sides. Swing the rope overhead and jump with both feet just high enough to clear the rope. Land softly on the balls of your feet. Keep a steady rhythm and minimize arm movement - the rotation should come from your wrists.

name: Jump Rope: Basic Bounce
description: The foundation of all jump rope skills. Jump with both feet together, landing softly on the balls of your feet. Keep knees slightly bent, core engaged, and elbows close to your sides. The rotation comes from your wrists, not your shoulders. Master this before moving to other skills.

name: Jump Rope: Boxer Step
description: Shift your weight from one foot to the other with each rope pass, like a boxer bouncing. Land lightly on the ball of one foot while the other hovers just off the ground. Keep knees soft and stay relaxed. This is the most efficient way to jump rope for longer sessions.

name: Jump Rope: Butt Kicks
description: Run in place while kicking your heels up toward your glutes with each step. The rope passes under one foot at a time. Keep your core tight and maintain quick, light footwork. This variation targets your hamstrings and increases workout intensity.

name: Jump Rope: Criss-Cross
description: Cross your arms in front of your body as the rope passes overhead, then uncross for the next rotation. Cross at hip level, not chest level. The key is timing - cross as the rope is coming down, jump through the loop, uncross as it comes back up. Practice the arm motion without jumping first.

name: Jump Rope: Double Under
description: Swing the rope fast enough to pass under your feet twice per jump. Jump higher than normal and spin the rope faster with quick wrist flicks. Keep your core tight and elbows close to your sides. Start with singles, then attempt 1 double, then build up consecutive doubles.

name: Jump Rope: Front-Back Hops
description: Jump forward and backward with each rope pass, landing with feet together. Keep hops small (6-12 inches). Imagine jumping over a line. Stay light on your feet and maintain a consistent rhythm. Great for developing timing and body control.

name: Jump Rope: Heel-Toe Step
description: Alternate tapping your heel forward then your toe backward with each rope pass. Right heel tap, right toe tap, left heel tap, left toe tap. Keep the movement small and controlled. This is a classic footwork pattern that improves coordination and looks smooth once mastered.

name: Jump Rope: High Knees
description: Drive your knees up toward your chest with each jump, alternating legs rapidly. Keep your core tight and pump your arms. This is an intense cardio variation - expect to be breathing hard quickly. Great for conditioning and building explosive power.

name: Jump Rope: Lateral Hops
description: Jump side to side with each rope pass, landing with feet together. Keep hops small (6-12 inches) and controlled. Imagine jumping over a line on the ground. This builds lateral agility and is great for sports that require quick side-to-side movement.

name: Jump Rope: Mummy Kicks
description: Alternate kicking each leg straight out in front of you with each rope pass, keeping legs relatively straight. Like a stiff-legged march or 'mummy walk'. Keep kicks low at first (6-12 inches off ground). This looks impressive and challenges your timing and hip mobility.

name: Jump Rope: Running in Place
description: Instead of jumping with both feet, run in place while turning the rope. Each foot hits the ground on alternating rope passes. Keep your knees slightly lifted and stay light on your toes. This is easier than regular jumping for some people and great for building endurance.

name: Jump Rope: Scissor Step
description: Alternate landing with one foot forward and one back in a split stance, switching positions with each jump. Like a lunge position but with small, quick switches. Keep your torso upright and stay light on your feet. Great for building coordination and lower body agility.

name: Jump Rope: Side Swing
description: Swing the rope to one side of your body in a figure-8 pattern without jumping through it. Alternate sides. This is a great active recovery move between intense jumping sets, and helps develop rope control and timing. Keep wrists relaxed and let the rope flow.

name: Jump Rope: Single Leg Hops
description: Jump on one foot for several rotations, then switch to the other foot. Keep the non-jumping foot slightly behind you for balance. This builds single-leg strength, balance, and coordination. Start with 5-10 jumps per leg before switching.

name: Jump Rope: Twist
description: Rotate your hips and legs left and right with each jump while keeping your upper body facing forward. Your feet should twist 45-90 degrees each direction. This engages your obliques and adds a fun coordination challenge. Keep the twist controlled and rhythmic.

name: Jumping Jacks
description: Start with feet together and arms at sides. Jump feet apart while raising arms overhead. Jump back to starting position.

name: A/B Stance Goblet Squat
description: A goblet squat variation alternating between two foot positions. Hold the kettlebell at chest height. 'A stance' is a wider sumo-style position targeting adductors and glutes. 'B stance' is a narrow, shoulder-width position emphasizing quads. Alternate between stances each rep or every few reps. The stance switching challenges balance and hits the legs from multiple angles in a single set.

name: Kettlebell Alternating Bent-Over Row
description: Hinge at the hips with a flat back, kettlebell in one hand. Row it to your hip, squeezing the shoulder blade at the top, then lower and pass the bell to the other hand at the bottom. Alternate sides each rep. Keep the body stable and avoid rotating the torso. The alternating pattern adds a core stability challenge.

name: Kettlebell Around-the-Body Pass
description: Hold the kettlebell with both hands at waist height. Pass it around your body in a smooth circle — hand to hand behind your back and in front. Keep your core tight and torso still. Alternate directions each set.

name: Kettlebell Bent-Over Straddle Squat
description: An unconventional kettlebell squat variation where the torso stays bent forward (nearly parallel to ground) throughout the movement. Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width, kettlebell on the floor between feet. Hinge at hips with a deep forward lean, squat down to grab the kettlebell, then drive up through the legs while maintaining the hunched-over position. This hybrid squat/good-morning pattern loads the posterior chain significantly more than a standard squat. Seen on social media (@powerbrutehq) - exercise name is informal as this is not a standard movement.

name: Kettlebell Bent Press
description: A classic old-time strongman lift. Start with the kettlebell in rack position. Instead of pressing the bell up, bend your torso AWAY from the bell while keeping the arm locked and the bell stationary. Your body moves under the weight rather than pressing it overhead. Requires significant shoulder mobility, core stability, and hip flexibility. One of the most efficient ways to get heavy weight overhead with one arm.

name: Kettlebell Chest Press
description: Lie on the floor (or a bench if available) with knees bent. Hold a kettlebell in one or both hands at chest level. Press the bell straight up to full arm extension, then lower under control until your upper arm touches the floor. Similar to a floor press but the kettlebell's offset center of mass adds a stabilization challenge. Keep elbows at roughly 45 degrees to protect the shoulders.

name: Kettlebell Clean and Press
description: Start with kettlebell on the floor. Clean it to the rack position at your shoulder by pulling it up close to your body and rotating your hand under. From the rack, press it overhead to full lockout. Lower back to rack, then back to the floor. Alternate sides or complete all reps on one side before switching.

name: Kettlebell Clean and Squat
description: Clean the kettlebell with both hands from the ground to the rack position at your chest, then immediately squat down until thighs are parallel. Drive through heels to stand. The two-hand clean makes this more beginner-friendly than a single-arm version. Explosive on the clean, controlled on the squat.

name: Close Grip Kettlebell Push Up
description: Place a kettlebell on its side or use two kettlebells. Grip the handles with both hands in a close/narrow grip. Perform pushups from this position, keeping elbows tucked close to the body. The narrow grip shifts emphasis to the triceps and inner chest. The elevated hand position also increases range of motion compared to floor pushups.

name: Kettlebell Dead Clean
description: Clean the kettlebell from a dead stop on the floor to the rack position. Unlike a swing clean, each rep starts from a complete standstill — no momentum. Hinge at the hips, grip the bell, and explosively drive through the hips to pull it into the rack. The dead stop makes each rep harder and builds raw pulling power.

name: Kettlebell Deadlift
description: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell centered between feet. Hinge at hips, push butt back, and grab the handle with both hands. Keep chest up, back flat, and shoulders pulled back. Drive through heels to stand tall, squeezing glutes at the top. Reverse the movement to lower the bell back to the floor with control.

name: Feet Elevated Pushup (on Kettlebell)
description: Place your feet on top of a kettlebell (on its side or upright) and perform pushups from this elevated position. The elevation shifts more load to the upper chest and shoulders compared to flat pushups. Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels. The slight instability from the kettlebell also engages your core. Modify on knees if needed.

name: Kettlebell Floor Press
description: Lie on the floor with knees bent. Hold a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder level, elbow on the ground. Press the bell straight up to full extension, then lower until the upper arm touches the floor again. The floor limits range of motion and eliminates leg drive, isolating the pressing muscles. Great for building lockout strength.

name: Kettlebell Front Squat
description: Clean one or two kettlebells to the rack position at shoulders. Feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly out. Squat down keeping elbows high and chest proud. The front-loaded weight demands more core and upper-back engagement than a back squat. Drive through heels to stand. Double kettlebell version is significantly harder.

name: Kettlebell Goblet Squat
description: A squat variation holding a kettlebell at chest height like a goblet. Stand with feet slightly wider than shoulder-width, toes pointed slightly outward. Hold the kettlebell by the horns (handles) at chest height, close to your body. Keeping your chest up and core tight, lower into a deep squat by pushing your hips back and bending your knees.
