Let your elbows track inside your knees at the bottom. Drive through your heels to stand back up. The front-loaded weight helps counterbalance and allows for a more upright torso, making this an excellent squat for building depth and proper form.

name: Kettlebell Halo
description: Hold the kettlebell upside down by the horns at chest level. Slowly rotate the bell around your head in a circle, passing it behind and back to the front. Keep your core tight, elbows close, and avoid moving your head. Alternate directions each rep. Great shoulder warmup and mobility exercise.

name: Kettlebell High Pull
description: Hold the kettlebell in front with both hands. Pull it explosively to shoulder height by driving with hips, shrugging the traps, and bending the elbows. Keep the bell close to your body. Lower with control.

name: Kettlebell Lateral Lunge
description: Hold the kettlebell in rack position or at chest. Step wide to one side, pushing hips back and bending the lunging knee while keeping the trailing leg straight. The lateral movement hits the adductors and outer glutes more than a forward lunge. Push off the lunging foot to return to start.

name: Kettlebell Lunge
description: Hold one or two kettlebells at your sides (suitcase style) or in the rack position. Step forward into a lunge, lowering until both knees are at approximately 90 degrees. Drive through the front heel to return to standing. Alternate legs or complete all reps on one side. Rack position adds a core stability challenge.

name: Overhead Kettlebell Lunge
description: Hold a kettlebell locked out overhead in one hand. Step forward into a lunge, lowering until both knees are at 90 degrees. Keep the arm fully extended and torso upright throughout. Drive through the front heel to return to standing. The overhead position demands serious shoulder stability and core engagement while the legs do the heavy work.

name: Kettlebell Overhead Press
description: Hold the kettlebell in the rack position at shoulder height, elbow tucked close to ribs. Brace your core and press the bell overhead to full lockout, rotating the wrist so palm faces forward at the top. Lower back to rack under control. The offset load challenges core stability more than a barbell press.

name: Overhead Kettlebell Squat
description: Hold a kettlebell locked out overhead in one hand. Squat down until thighs are at least parallel, keeping the arm fully extended and the bell directly over your shoulder. Drive through heels to stand. This demands excellent shoulder mobility, thoracic extension, and ankle flexibility. One of the best total-body stability exercises. Keep core braced and avoid arching the lower back.

name: Kettlebell Push Press
description: Hold the kettlebell in the rack position at your shoulder. Dip slightly at the knees (quarter squat), then explosively drive through the legs to help press the bell overhead to full lockout. The leg dip lets you move heavier weight than a strict press. Lower the bell back to rack under control. Power comes from the legs, not just the arms.

name: Kettlebell Row
description: Hinge forward at hips to about 45 degrees, one hand on a bench or knee for support. With the other hand, pull the kettlebell from a dead hang to your hip, squeezing the shoulder blade at the top. Lower under control. Keep core braced and avoid rotating the torso.

name: Kettlebell Side-to-Side Swing
description: Hold the kettlebell with both hands and swing it side to side across your body in a controlled arc. Maintain a slight squat stance and engage your core. Drive momentum from the hips, not the arms.

name: Kettlebell Straddle Squat
description: Place a kettlebell on the floor between your feet set wider than shoulder-width. Keeping chest upright and core braced, squat down by pushing hips back and bending knees. Reach down to touch or grab the kettlebell at the bottom while maintaining an upright torso. Drive through heels to stand. Similar to a sumo deadlift stance but with a full squat depth. The wide stance and upright torso emphasize the quads and inner thighs.

name: Kettlebell Suitcase Deadlift
description: Hold a kettlebell in one hand at your side like a suitcase. Hinge at the hips to lower the weight toward the ground while keeping your back straight and resisting the urge to lean to the loaded side. Drive through heels to stand tall. The offset load forces your core and obliques to work overtime to keep you upright. Great anti-lateral-flexion exercise.

name: Kettlebell Sumo Deadlift
description: Stand with feet wide apart, toes pointed out at about 45 degrees. Kettlebell centered between feet. Push hips back and bend knees to grab the bell with both hands. Keep chest tall and back flat. Drive through heels, squeeze glutes at the top to stand. The wide stance targets inner thighs and glutes more than a conventional deadlift.

name: Kettlebell Swing
description: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell on the floor slightly in front. Hinge at hips to grab the handle with both hands. Hike the bell back between legs then explosively drive hips forward to swing the kettlebell to chest height. Arms stay straight - power comes from the hip snap. Let it swing back between legs and repeat. Russian-style swing ends at chest height.

name: Kettlebell Swing Clean
description: A single-arm clean that starts from a swing. Hike the kettlebell back between legs, then use an explosive hip snap to swing it up and rotate it into the front rack position at your shoulder. Thumb should land on the collarbone, elbow tucked. The swing momentum makes the clean smoother than a dead clean from the floor.

name: Kettlebell Swing Snatch
description: Single-arm snatch starting from a swing. Hike the bell back, explosively drive hips forward, and guide the kettlebell overhead in one fluid motion. Punch through at the top to lock out the arm. Avoid letting the bell bang your forearm by keeping it close and rotating smoothly. The king of kettlebell exercises for cardio and power.

name: Kettlebell Tactical Clean
description: A clean variation that emphasizes control and precision. From the floor or hang position, clean the kettlebell to rack using a threading or rotational motion. Often used as a transition movement in kettlebell flows and complexes. The 'tactical' element comes from the controlled, deliberate nature of the movement — no unnecessary momentum.

name: Kettlebell Thruster
description: Hold one or two kettlebells in the rack position at shoulders. Squat down to at least parallel, then explosively drive up and use the momentum to press the kettlebells overhead. Lock out at the top, then lower bells back to rack as you descend into the next squat in one fluid motion. Great metabolic conditioning exercise.

name: Kettlebell Turkish Get-Up
description: Start lying on the floor, kettlebell locked out overhead in one hand. Methodically rise to standing through a series of positions: roll to elbow, post to hand, bridge hips, sweep leg through to half-kneeling, then stand. Reverse the sequence to return to the floor. Keep eyes on the bell and arm locked out throughout. One of the best full-body stability exercises.

name: Knee Push-up
description: Start in a push-up position with knees on the ground instead of toes. Keep body straight from knees to head. Lower chest toward the ground, then push back up. Focus on full range of motion and proper form.

name: Kneeling Ab Wheel Rollout
description: Kneel on the floor with an ab wheel (or use a towel on a smooth floor). Roll forward, extending your body as far as you can while maintaining a tight core. Don't let your lower back arch. Roll back to the starting position with control.

name: L-Hang
description: A dead hang with legs raised to form an L-shape. Hang from a bar with arms extended. Engage your core and hip flexors to raise your straight legs until they're parallel to the ground, forming a 90-degree angle with your torso. Hold this position. Keep legs straight and together, toes pointed. Shoulders should be active (not completely relaxed). This builds core compression strength, hip flexor endurance, and grip - all essential for advanced movements like L-sit pull-ups, toes-to-bar, and front levers. Start with tuck hangs (knees bent) if full L-hang is too difficult. Work toward 15-30 second holds.

name: L-Sit
description: A fundamental gymnastics hold where you support your body on your hands with legs extended horizontally. Sit on the floor (or use parallettes/push-up bars for easier clearance) with legs straight in front of you. Place hands beside your hips, fingers pointing forward. Press down through your palms, straighten your arms, and lift your entire body off the ground. Keep legs straight and together, parallel to the floor, forming an L-shape with your torso. Hold this position with core engaged and shoulders depressed. This requires significant core compression strength, hip flexor endurance, tricep strength, and shoulder stability. Progress from tuck L-sits (knees bent) to one-leg extended to full L-sit.

name: L-Sit Pull-up
description: A pull-up performed while holding an L-sit position. Hang from a bar and raise your straight legs until they're parallel to the ground (L-position). Hold this leg position throughout the movement. Perform a pull-up while maintaining the L-sit - chin over bar, then lower with control. The L-sit adds significant core and hip flexor demand while also changing the pulling angle. This exercise builds serious functional strength. Prerequisites: solid pull-ups and L-hang holds. If full L-sit is too difficult, start with a tuck (knees bent) and progress to straight legs.

name: Lat Pulldown
description: Sit at the lat pulldown machine with your thighs secured under the pads. Grip the bar slightly wider than shoulder-width with palms facing away. Lean back slightly and pull the bar down toward your upper chest, leading with your elbows. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the bottom of the movement. Control the weight back up, fully extending your arms without shrugging your shoulders. Focus on feeling your lats engage throughout the movement.

name: Lateral Raise
description: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding dumbbells at your sides with palms facing in. Raise the weights out to your sides until they reach shoulder height, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. Lower with control. Targets the middle deltoids.

name: Lateral Squat
description: Stand with feet wide apart. Shift your weight to one side, bending that knee and pushing your hips back while keeping the other leg straight. Your bent knee should track over your toes. Push back to center and repeat on the other side. Great for hip mobility and inner thigh strength.

name: Lateral to Front Raise
description: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding dumbbells at your sides with palms facing in. Raise the weights out to your sides (lateral raise) until they reach shoulder height. Hold briefly, then rotate your arms forward so the weights are now in front of you at shoulder height. Lower the weights back down to your sides with control. This compound shoulder isolation movement targets both the lateral and anterior deltoids in one fluid sequence. Can also be performed in reverse (front to side to down).

name: Leg Curl Machine
description: Lie face down on the machine with pad just above your ankles. Grip the handles and curl your heels toward your glutes, squeezing your hamstrings at the top. Lower with control - don't let the weight slam. Keep your hips pressed into the pad throughout. This isolates the hamstrings without loading the spine.

name: Leg Extension Machine
description: Sit with back against pad and ankles behind the roller pad. Grip handles and extend your legs until straight, squeezing quads at the top. Lower with control - this is where the muscle builds. Don't swing or use momentum. Great for targeting the quads without loading the spine.

name: Leg Kicks on Back
description: Lie on your back with shoulders slightly lifted and hands by your sides or under your glutes for support. Perform controlled kicking motions with straight legs, alternating between legs. Different from flutter kicks - these are larger, more deliberate kicks rather than small, rapid flutters.

name: Leg Press
description: Sit in the leg press machine with feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. Release the safety handles and lower the platform by bending your knees toward your chest until thighs are at 90 degrees. Push through your heels to extend your legs without locking your knees. Keep your lower back pressed firmly against the pad throughout the movement.

name: Leg Raise Compression
description: Sit on the floor with legs extended straight in front of you. Place your hands beside your hips. Keeping legs straight, lift them as high as possible using your hip flexors, trying to bring your thighs toward your chest. Lower with control. This is pure hip flexor compression work - essential for L-sits, V-sits, and manna. Focus on the active lift from your hip flexors, not momentum.

name: Lying Leg Raises
description: Lie on your back with legs straight. Keeping legs together, lift them up to 90 degrees, then lower slowly back down without touching the floor.

name: Leg Straddle Reaches
description: Lie on your back with legs raised and spread wide in a straddle position. Crunch up and reach your hands through the middle of your legs toward the floor beyond them. Lower back down with control. Targets the abs while engaging inner thighs in the straddle position.

name: Leg Up Flutter Kicks
description: Lie on your back with both legs raised to about 45-60 degrees off the floor. Perform flutter kicks in this elevated position - small, rapid alternating kicks. Keep your lower back pressed into the floor and shoulders slightly lifted. The elevated starting position increases the challenge.

name: Lower Back Raises
description: Lie face down on the floor with arms at your sides, palms facing up, or hands behind your head. Keep your legs straight and together. Slowly raise your upper body (chest and shoulders) off the floor by extending your lower back, lifting as high as comfortable without hyperextending. Squeeze your glutes and lower back muscles at the top. Lower back down with control. Focus on using your erector spinae (lower back muscles) to lift, not momentum. Keep your neck in a neutral position - don't crane it upward. This strengthens the posterior chain and improves spinal stability. Can be done with arms extended overhead for added difficulty.

name: Lunge Knee Up
description: Start standing with feet hip-width apart. Step back into a reverse lunge, lowering your back knee toward the floor. Explosively drive up through your front foot while bringing your back knee up toward your chest. Return to the lunge position and repeat. Alternate legs or complete all reps on one side before switching.

name: Lying Knee to Chest Crunch
description: Lie on your back with hands and heels on the floor, head pointed toward your feet. Engage your core and bring your knees up toward your chest in a crunching motion, then extend legs back out. Keep your upper back off the ground throughout.

name: Lying Knee Tucks
description: Lie on your back with legs extended. Bring knees toward your chest in a controlled manner, then extend back out without touching the floor. Keep lower back pressed to the floor throughout the movement.

name: Lying Single Leg Push
description: Lie on your back with both knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Extend one leg straight up toward the ceiling. Press through the heel of your grounded foot to lift your hips off the floor, creating a straight line from your shoulders to your knee. Keep the extended leg reaching upward throughout. Squeeze your glutes at the top, then lower with control. This single-leg bridge variation isolates each glute independently.

name: Lying Windshield Wipers
description: Lie on back with legs raised to 90 degrees. Keep legs straight and slowly rotate from side to side in a windshield wiper motion, controlling the movement with your core. Do not let lower back lift off the floor.

name: Malasana Hold (Garland Pose)
description: Also known as Asian squat or deep squat hold. Squat down with feet flat (or heels on a yoga block if mobility is limited), knees wide, and hands in prayer position at your chest. Use your elbows to gently press your knees open. Keep your spine long and chest lifted. This pose opens the hips, stretches the groin, and improves ankle mobility. Can be held for extended periods - traditionally used as a resting position for work or eating.

name: McGill Crunch
description: Lie on your back with one hand placed behind your lower back to maintain the natural curve of your spine. Keep one leg straight on the floor and the other leg bent with foot flat. Place your other hand behind your head for support. Slowly raise your head, neck, and shoulders just a few inches off the floor (not a full sit-up) while keeping your lower back pressed against your hand. Hold this position briefly, then lower slowly. The key is minimal movement with maximum muscle activation. Great for posture checking and core warmup. This is part of Dr. Stuart McGill's Big 3 core stability exercises.

media.caption: Dr. Stuart McGill demonstrating the McGill Crunch

name: Mountain Climbers
description: Start in high plank position with hands under shoulders. Drive one knee toward chest, then quickly switch legs in a running motion. Keep hips low and core engaged. Maintain a steady, quick rhythm.

name: Muscle-up
description: A complete pulling-to-pushing movement: pull yourself up and over the bar (or rings) to end in a dip support position. From a dead hang, perform an explosive pull-up while driving your chest toward the bar. As your chest reaches bar height, lean forward aggressively and transition your hands from pulling to pushing, rolling over the bar. Press up to full arm extension in the support position. The key is the transition - the pull must be high enough and the forward lean aggressive enough to get over the bar. Bar muscle-ups typically use a kip; ring muscle-ups rely more on a false grip and strength. Prerequisites: 10+ pull-ups, dips, and ideally false grip work on rings.

name: Negative Dip
description: Start at the top of the dip position on parallel bars. Slowly lower yourself down over 3-5 seconds until your shoulders are below your elbows. Use your legs or a box to return to the top position and repeat.

name: Negative Pull-up
description: Jump or use a box to get to the top of a pull-up position (chin over bar). Slowly lower yourself down over 3-5 seconds, fighting gravity the entire way. Focus on control and keeping your core engaged. Reset and repeat.

name: Nordic Curl
description: Kneel with feet anchored under something sturdy. Keep your body straight from knees to head. Slowly lower yourself forward, controlling the descent with your hamstrings. Go as low as possible, then use your hands to push back up.

name: Oblique Plank Crunches
description: Start in forearm plank position. Crunch your right side by bringing right knee toward right elbow, return to plank, then crunch left side. Alternate sides in a controlled manner. Targets core and obliques together.

name: One-Arm Pull-up Negative
description: The eccentric-only version of a one-arm pull-up - essential for building toward the full movement. Jump or use assistance to get to the top position (chin over bar) while holding with one arm. Slowly lower yourself down using only that arm, fighting gravity the entire way. Aim for a 5-10 second descent. The free arm can be held out to the side or placed on your chest. This builds the specific strength needed for one-arm pull-ups. Prerequisites: 15+ strict pull-ups, archer pull-ups, and good grip strength. Alternate arms each rep to prevent imbalances.

name: Overhead Press
description: Stand with barbell at shoulder height. Press the bar straight overhead until arms are fully extended. Lower back to shoulders.

name: Overhead Tricep Extension
description: Stand or sit holding one dumbbell overhead with both hands. Lower the weight behind your head by bending at the elbows while keeping upper arms vertical. Extend arms back to starting position. Keep core tight and avoid arching your back.

name: Pallof Press
description: Attach a resistance band at chest height. Stand sideways to the anchor point, holding the band at your chest. Press the band straight out in front of you, resisting the rotational pull. Hold for a moment, then bring hands back to chest. Keep hips square throughout.

name: Pec Deck Fly
description: Sit with back flat against pad, elbows at 90 degrees on the arm pads. Squeeze your chest to bring the pads together in front of you. Focus on the contraction at the center, not just moving the weight. Control the movement back, feeling the stretch in your chest. Keep shoulders down and avoid shrugging. Excellent for chest isolation and mind-muscle connection.

name: Penguins
description: Sit with knees bent and feet slightly off the floor. Lean back slightly and tap each side of your torso with your hands in quick alternating motions, like a penguin waddling. Maintain core tension throughout.

name: Pigeon Pose
description: From all fours, bring one knee forward and angle it toward the same-side wrist, with your shin roughly parallel to the front of the mat. Extend the back leg straight behind you. Square your hips and fold forward over your front leg. Hold for 60 seconds. This is one of the deepest hip openers, targeting the hip rotators and flexors.

name: Pike Crunches
description: Start in high plank position. Pike your hips high, bringing them up toward the ceiling while keeping legs straight, then return to plank. This combines a pike hold with core engagement, targeting abs and shoulders.

name: Pike Hold
description: From lying on your back, lift both legs and torso to meet in a pike position and hold at the top. Your body forms a V-shape with legs straight and together, reaching hands toward feet. Maintain the elevated position with core engaged, keeping shoulders and legs off the ground. This static hold builds the compression strength dancers and gymnasts need.

name: Pike Push-ups
description: Start in downward dog position with hips raised high, forming an inverted V. Bend elbows to lower your head toward the floor between your hands. Push back up. Great for building shoulder strength and progressing toward handstand push-ups.

name: Pike to Cobra Worms
description: From a plank position, push hips up into pike position, then lower into an upward-facing dog position (cobra), followed by a worm-like motion through a push-up, flowing back to pike. Repeat continuously in a flowing movement.

name: Pike Up
description: Lie on your back with arms extended overhead and legs together and straight. In one controlled movement, pike up by lifting both your legs and torso simultaneously, reaching your hands toward your feet at the top. Lower back down with control, keeping legs together throughout. This is the foundational pike movement used in dance and gymnastics conditioning.

name: Pistol Squat
description: Stand on one leg with the other leg extended straight in front of you. Lower into a deep single-leg squat while keeping the extended leg off the ground. Push through your heel to stand back up. Requires significant strength and mobility.

name: Pistol Squat to Box
description: Stand on one leg in front of a box, bench, or chair. Extend the other leg straight in front. Lower into a single-leg squat until you tap the box with your glutes, then stand back up. The box provides a safety target and makes the movement easier than a full pistol squat. Great for building single-leg strength, especially on the left side.

name: Planche Lean (Front Support Hold)
description: A foundational planche progression exercise. Start in a push-up position with hands on the floor, fingers pointing forward. Lean your shoulders forward past your fingertips while keeping your feet on the ground and arms straight. Your body should form an angle with the ground - the more you lean forward, the harder it becomes. Keep your core tight, maintain a straight body line, and protract your shoulder blades (push them away from your spine). Hold this position. This builds the straight arm scapular strength (SASS) and core stability needed for planche training. Start with shorter holds (10-30 seconds) and gradually increase as strength improves.

name: Planche Push-up
description: An advanced calisthenics movement where your body is held horizontally parallel to the ground, supported only by your hands, while performing a pushing motion. Start in a planche position (body horizontal, feet off ground) - this can be tuck planche, advanced tuck, straddle, or full planche depending on your level. With straight arms, lower your body by bending your elbows, keeping your body horizontal throughout. Press back up to full arm extension. Requires exceptional upper-body strength, core stability, and total-body control. Prerequisites include planche lean holds (30-60 seconds), tuck planche holds, strong core, and wrist conditioning. Keep your core rigid and maintain a straight body line from head to heels throughout the movement.

name: Plank
description: Support your body on forearms and toes, keeping a straight line from head to heels. Engage your core by pulling belly button toward spine. Don't let hips sag or pike up. Hold the position and breathe steadily.

name: Plank Arm Reach
description: Start in high plank position. Without rotating hips, reach one arm forward as far as possible while maintaining balance, then return. Alternate sides. This challenges core stability and anti-rotation strength.

name: Plank Crunches
description: From a plank position, alternate bringing your knees toward your chest in a crunching motion. Maintain a strong plank throughout the movement.

name: Plank Forward Shifts
description: Start in a high plank or forearm plank position. Shift your entire body forward by pushing through your toes, moving your shoulders past your hands. Then shift back to the starting position. Keep your body in a straight line throughout. This increases shoulder and core engagement.

name: Plank Hip Dips
description: Start in forearm plank position. Rotate hips to lower right hip toward the floor, then return to center. Repeat on left side. Keep core tight and movement controlled throughout.

name: Plank Jacks
description: Start in high plank position. Jump or step your feet out wide, then back together in a jumping jack motion while maintaining a rigid plank. Keep hips level and core engaged throughout. Great for cardio and core stability.

name: Plank Lateral Shifts
description: Start in a high plank position. Keeping your body rigid, shift your weight to one side, moving your entire body laterally. Return to center and shift to the other side. This lateral movement challenges obliques and shoulder stability in a unique way.

name: Plank Leg Raise
description: Start in a high plank or forearm plank position. Keeping your hips level and core tight, lift one leg straight up behind you. Hold briefly at the top, then lower with control. Alternate legs. Focus on preventing hip rotation as you lift each leg.

name: Plank Pulses
description: From a plank position with hands shoulder-width apart, perform small pulses by moving your body forward and backward a few inches while maintaining core engagement. Keep hips level and don't let your lower back sag.

name: Plank Shoulder Taps
description: Start in a high plank position. Keeping your hips stable, lift one hand to tap the opposite shoulder. Return and repeat on the other side. Minimize hip rotation throughout.

name: Plank to Down Dog
description: Start in a high plank position. Push your hips up and back into a downward dog position, forming an inverted V shape with your body. Hold briefly, then lower back to plank position. This dynamic movement stretches the posterior chain while engaging the core and shoulders.

name: Plank to Star
description: Start in a high plank position. Rotate your body to one side while lifting your top arm toward the ceiling, forming a star or T shape. Your body should form a straight line from fingertip to fingertip. Return to plank and repeat on the other side. Excellent for rotational core strength and shoulder stability.

name: Plank Up Downs
description: Start in a high plank position. Lower one arm at a time to forearm plank, then push back up to high plank one arm at a time. Alternate which arm leads.

name: Plank Walkout
description: Stand with feet hip-width apart. Bend at the hips and place your hands on the floor in front of you. Walk your hands forward into a plank position, keeping your core tight. Hold the plank briefly, then walk your hands back to your feet and return to standing. This dynamically warms up the entire body - core, shoulders, and hamstrings.

name: Plank with Arm Reach
description: Start in a high plank position. Keeping your hips level and core tight, extend one arm straight out in front of you. Hold briefly, then return to plank. Alternate arms. Focus on preventing hip rotation and maintaining a stable plank position throughout.

name: Plié Squats
description: Stand with feet wide and toes turned out. Lower into a squat while keeping torso upright and knees tracking over toes.

name: Plow Pose (Halasana)
description: Lie on your back and lift your legs over your head, lowering your toes to the floor behind your head. Keep your legs straight and support your lower back with your hands, or extend arms along the floor for a deeper stretch. Your weight should be on your shoulders, not your neck. This pose stretches the entire posterior chain and calms the nervous system. Hold for 30-60 seconds. Contraindicated for those with neck injuries.

name: Prone Leg Raise with Back Extension
description: Lie face down (on your chest) with arms at your sides or under your forehead. Lift your legs up off the floor while simultaneously lifting your chest into a back extension/cobra position. Lower both with control. This combines posterior chain work with spinal extension.

name: Prone Leg Raises (Back Lever Prep)
description: Lie face down with arms extended overhead or at your sides. Keep your legs straight and lift them as high as possible off the ground, squeezing your glutes and lower back. Hold briefly at the top, then lower with control. This strengthens the posterior chain in the exact position needed for back lever progressions. Focus on lifting from the glutes and back, not momentum.

name: Prone T-Raises
description: Lie face down with arms extended out to the sides in a T position. Lift your arms and chest off the floor, squeezing your back and shoulder blades together. Lower with control. Targets lateral back and shoulder muscles.

name: Prone W-Raises
description: Lie face down with arms bent at 90 degrees at your sides, creating a W shape. Lift your arms and chest off the floor, keeping elbows bent. Lower with control. Emphasizes middle and upper back activation.

name: Prone Y-Raises
description: Lie face down with arms extended overhead forming a Y shape. Lift your arms and chest off the floor together, squeezing your back and shoulder muscles. Hold briefly, then lower. Great for posterior chain activation.

name: Pseudo Planche Push-up
description: A push-up performed with hands placed near your hips instead of at shoulder level. Start in a planche lean position (hands by your waist, fingers pointing sideways or back, leaning forward over your hands). Perform a push-up in this position, lowering your chest toward the ground while maintaining the forward lean. Press back up. The further your hands are toward your hips and the more you lean forward, the harder it becomes. This builds the specific pushing strength needed for planche training. Keep core tight and body in a straight line. This bridges the gap between regular push-ups and tuck planche.

name: Pull-up
description: Hang from a pull-up bar with hands shoulder-width apart, palms facing away. Pull yourself up until chin clears the bar.

name: Pull-up with Scapular Shrug
description: A pull-up that emphasizes scapular engagement and retraction at the top of the movement. Hang from a pull-up bar with hands shoulder-width apart, palms facing away. Start by performing a scapular pull - depress and retract your shoulder blades while keeping arms straight. Then pull yourself up until your chin clears the bar. At the top, actively squeeze your shoulder blades together and down, creating an extra 'shrug' of retraction. Lower with control, maintaining scapular engagement until the bottom. This reinforces proper back activation during pulling movements and builds the scapular strength needed for advanced calisthenics like front levers and muscle-ups.

name: Push Press
description: Stand with barbell or dumbbells at shoulder height. Slightly dip down by bending your knees and hips, then explosively drive up with your legs while pressing the weight overhead. The leg drive helps you press more weight than a strict press. Lower back to shoulders with control.

name: Push-up
description: Start in plank position with hands shoulder-width apart. Keep body straight from head to heels. Lower chest toward the floor by bending elbows, then push back up to starting position. Keep core engaged throughout.

name: Push-up Star
description: Perform a push-up. At the top of the movement, rotate your body to one side and extend your top arm toward the ceiling, forming a star or T shape. Return to plank, perform another push-up, then rotate to the other side. Combines pressing strength with rotational core work.

name: Push-up Walk to Standing
description: Start standing. Fold forward and walk your hands out to a push-up position. Perform a push-up, then walk your hands back toward your feet and stand up. This combines core stabilization, upper body strength, and hamstring flexibility in one flowing movement.

name: Quick Bicycles
description: Perform bicycle crunches at maximum speed. Hands behind head, rapidly alternate bringing elbow to opposite knee in a pedaling motion. Keep the pace quick and consistent - this is about speed, not range. Maintain core engagement throughout and avoid pulling on your neck. Count each elbow-to-knee touch as one rep.

name: Quick Scissors
description: Lie on your back with legs lifted at 45 degrees, shoulders slightly raised. Rapidly criss-cross your legs over and under each other in quick scissoring movements. Move at maximum speed while keeping legs straight and core engaged. The quicker the better - this is about speed and coordination, not range of motion.

name: Quick V-Ups
description: Perform V-ups at an accelerated pace. Lie flat, then explosively bring legs and torso up to meet in a V-shape, touching hands to feet. Quickly lower and immediately repeat. Focus on rapid transitions rather than holding at the top. This explosive version builds power and cardiovascular endurance alongside core strength.

name: Raised Ball Lunge
description: Stand in front of a stability ball with one foot placed on top of the ball behind you (Bulgarian split squat position with ball). Keep your front foot firmly planted and core engaged. Lower your body by bending your front knee until your thigh is parallel to the ground. Push through your front heel to return to standing. The unstable surface of the ball increases core and stabilizer engagement.

name: Relevé (Calf Raises)
description: Stand with feet together or in ballet position. Rise up onto the balls of your feet, lifting heels as high as possible.

name: Renegade Row
description: Start in a high plank position with each hand on a dumbbell, feet wider than hip-width for stability. Keeping your hips level and core tight, row one dumbbell up to your ribcage, elbow close to your body. Lower with control and repeat on the other side. Minimize hip rotation throughout - this is as much a core exercise as it is a back exercise.

name: Reverse Crunches
description: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on floor. Roll your pelvis up to lift your lower back off the floor while keeping your upper back down. Return to starting position. This targets lower abs effectively.

name: Reverse Hyper
description: Lie face down on a bench or elevated surface with hips at the edge and legs hanging off. Hold onto the bench for support. Raise your legs by squeezing your glutes until they're in line with your body. Lower with control and repeat.

name: Reverse Snow Angels
description: Lie face down with arms extended overhead. Lift chest and arms off the ground. Sweep arms down toward your hips in an arc, then return to starting position in a snow angel motion.

name: Reverse Table Knee Tuck
description: Sit on the floor with hands behind you and feet in front, creating a reverse table top position with hips lifted and body facing up. Your head points toward your feet. From this position, crunch your knees toward your face/chest while maintaining the reverse table position with your hands and feet on the floor. Extend legs back out and repeat. Works the entire core.

name: Ring Dip
description: A dip performed on gymnastics rings - significantly harder than parallel bar dips due to stability demands. Start in a support hold at the top of the rings with arms straight, rings turned out slightly, and body upright. Keep the rings close to your body. Lower yourself by bending your elbows until your shoulders are below your elbows (or as deep as mobility allows). Press back up to full arm extension. The rings want to move apart, so you must actively squeeze them in while pushing. Keep your core tight and avoid excessive swinging. Master support holds and parallel bar dips before attempting ring dips. These build incredible pushing strength and shoulder stability.

name: Ring False Grip Row
description: An inverted row performed on rings using a false grip - essential training for muscle-ups. Set rings at hip height and hang underneath with feet on the floor. Use a false grip: instead of gripping the rings in your palm, wrap your wrist over the ring so the bottom of your palm sits on top of the ring. This positions your wrist deep in the ring. Pull your chest to the rings while maintaining the false grip, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Lower with control. The false grip is uncomfortable at first but is prerequisite for ring muscle-ups. Start with feet elevated less to make it easier, progress to feet elevated on a box for full difficulty.

name: Ring Muscle-up
description: A muscle-up performed on gymnastics rings - often considered easier than bar muscle-ups due to the rings' freedom of movement. Start in a dead hang with a false grip (wrists wrapped over the rings). Pull powerfully, keeping the rings close to your body. As your chest reaches ring height, lean forward aggressively and transition by rotating your hands, moving from below the rings to above them. Press up to support hold. The false grip is essential - without it, the transition is nearly impossible. The rings can move with you, making the transition smoother than on a fixed bar. Prerequisites: false grip rows, ring dips, and 10+ pull-ups.

name: Assisted Ring Pull-up
description: A ring pull-up with feet on the ground for assistance - perfect for building toward full ring pull-ups. Set rings at a height where you can hold them while standing with arms extended overhead. Keep your feet on the ground, walking them forward so your body is at an angle. Pull yourself up by driving your elbows down, bringing your chest toward the rings. The more you walk your feet forward (body more horizontal), the harder it becomes. Keep your body straight from head to heels, core engaged throughout. This builds the pulling strength and ring stability needed for full ring pull-ups while allowing you to control the difficulty.

name: Ring Rows
description: An adjustable bodyweight row performed on gymnastic rings. Set rings at hip height. Grab the rings and walk your feet forward, leaning back until your arms are extended. The more horizontal your body, the harder the exercise. Pull yourself up by driving your elbows back, squeezing your shoulder blades together, and bringing the rings to your chest. Lower with control. Keep your body rigid like a plank throughout. Rings allow natural rotation of the hands during the pull, which is easier on the joints than fixed bars. Adjust difficulty by changing body angle - more upright is easier, more horizontal is harder.

name: Ring Support Hold
description: The top position of a ring dip, held as an isometric. Support yourself on rings with arms straight and locked. Rings should be turned out (palms facing forward, or RTO) for the full gymnastics standard - this is significantly harder than neutral grip. Keep your body upright, core tight, and shoulders depressed. The rings want to move - you must actively squeeze them in and stabilize. This builds the shoulder stability and straight-arm strength fundamental to all ring work. Master this before attempting ring dips. Work toward 30-60 seconds with rings turned out. The ring support is a strength feat in itself.

name: Romanian Deadlift
description: Stand with feet hip-width apart. Push your hips back while keeping a slight bend in knees and back straight. Lower your torso until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. Squeeze glutes to return to standing.

name: Running
description: Maintain a steady pace with good posture. Land midfoot and push off with toes. Keep arms bent at 90 degrees, swinging naturally.

name: Russian Twists
description: Sit with knees bent, feet lifted slightly off floor, lean back at 45 degrees. Clasp hands together and rotate torso to touch the floor on each side. Keep core engaged and move with control, not momentum.

name: Scapular Pull
description: Hang from a pull-up bar with arms fully extended. Without bending your elbows, pull your shoulder blades down and together, raising your body slightly. Hold briefly at the top, then lower with control. Focus on using only your back muscles.

name: Scissor Kicks
description: Lie on your back with legs extended and shoulders slightly lifted. Raise both legs off the floor. Cross one leg over the other in a controlled scissoring motion, then switch - alternating which leg is on top. Keep legs straight and core engaged throughout. Unlike flutter kicks (up/down), scissor kicks move legs side-to-side, crossing over and under each other.

name: Seated Cable Row
description: Sit at the cable row machine with feet on the footrests and knees slightly bent. Grip the handle with arms fully extended, maintaining a tall spine. Pull the handle toward your lower chest/upper abdomen, driving your elbows back and squeezing your shoulder blades together. Keep your torso stable - avoid swinging or using momentum. Control the weight back to the starting position with a slow eccentric. Focus on the mind-muscle connection with your mid-back.

name: Seated Dumbbell Shoulder Press
description: Sit on a bench with back support, holding dumbbells at shoulder height with palms facing forward. Press the weights overhead until arms are fully extended. Lower back to shoulder height with control. The seated position provides more stability and allows you to focus on shoulder strength without core compensation.

name: Shoulder Press Machine
description: Adjust seat so handles start at shoulder height. Sit with back against pad, core engaged. Press handles overhead until arms are nearly straight (don't lock). Lower with control to starting position. Keep your wrists neutral and avoid arching your back. Great for building shoulder strength safely.

name: Shoulder Stand (Sarvangasana)
description: Lie on your back with arms along your sides. Lift your legs up and over, then press your hips up toward the ceiling, supporting your lower back with your hands. Extend legs straight up so your body forms a vertical line from shoulders to toes. Weight should be on your shoulders and upper arms, not your neck. Hold the position while breathing steadily. A precursor to Plow Pose.

name: Side Climbers
description: Start in a plank position. Alternate bringing your knees up toward one side of your body, creating a dynamic climbing motion that targets the obliques and core.

name: Side Crunches
description: Lie on your side with knees bent. Crunch your upper body toward your knees, focusing on the obliques. Repeat on both sides.

name: Side Lying Oblique Crunch
description: Lie on your side with legs stacked and slightly bent. Place your bottom arm on the floor for support and top hand behind your head. Crunch your upper body toward your hip, contracting your obliques. Lower with control. Complete all reps on one side before switching.

name: Side Plank Hip Dips
description: Start in side plank position on one forearm. Lower your hip toward the floor, then raise back to plank. Keep your body in a straight line throughout. Repeat on one side, then switch sides.

name: Side Plank Hold
description: Lie on your side and prop yourself up on your forearm, elbow directly under shoulder. Stack your feet or stagger them for easier balance. Lift your hips off the ground to form a straight line from head to feet. Brace your core and squeeze your obliques hard. Hold this position with maximum muscle activation and tension. Breathe normally while maintaining the hold. Perform on both sides. Part of Dr. Stuart McGill's Big 3 core stability exercises - focus on quality of contraction over duration.

name: Side Plank Push-up
description: Start in push-up position. Perform a push-up, then rotate into a side plank with one arm extended toward the ceiling. Return to push-up position and perform another push-up, then rotate to side plank on the other side. This combines pushing strength with rotational core stability and shoulder stability in the support position.

name: Side Plank Thread the Needle
description: Start in a side plank with your top arm extended toward the ceiling. Rotate your torso and thread your top arm under your body, reaching behind you. Rotate back to the starting position with arm extended up. Perform all reps on one side before switching.

name: Side to Side Reaches (Supine Heel Touches)
description: A controlled oblique activation exercise that emphasizes lateral core stability. Lie on your back with knees bent, feet flat on the floor about hip-width apart. Arms straight by your sides, palms down. Lift your head and shoulders slightly off the mat into a mini-crunch position - just enough to engage your abs but not straining your neck. MAINTAINING this position with your core engaged, reach your right hand toward your right heel by side-bending through your waist - sliding your hand along the floor. You should feel your right oblique contract. Return to center, then reach your left hand toward your left heel. Move SLOWLY and with control - this is not about speed. Keep your lower back pressed into the mat throughout. The movement is a controlled side-bend, not a full twist. Think of shortening one side of your waist while lengthening the other. Each reach (left or right) = 1 rep. Alternate sides smoothly. If your neck gets tired, rest briefly and resume.

name: Single Leg Deadlift
description: Stand on one leg with a slight knee bend. Hinge at the hips, extending the free leg behind you for balance while lowering your torso toward the ground. Keep back straight. Return to standing by squeezing glutes.

name: Single Leg Good Morning
description: Stand on one leg with a slight bend in the knee. Place your hands behind your head or crossed over your chest. Keeping your back straight and core engaged, hinge forward at the hips while simultaneously extending your non-standing leg straight behind you. Lower your torso until it is nearly parallel to the ground, maintaining a straight line from your head through your extended heel. Squeeze your hamstring and glute to return to standing. This exercise develops single-leg stability and posterior chain strength.

name: Single Leg Lunge
description: Stand on one leg with the other leg slightly lifted behind you. Step back into a reverse lunge, lowering your back knee toward the floor while keeping most of your weight on the front foot. Push through the front heel to return to standing. Complete all reps on one side before switching. Focus on control and balance.

name: Single Leg Pike Up (Left)
description: Lie on your back with arms extended overhead and legs straight. Keeping your right leg down, pike your left leg up while simultaneously lifting your torso, reaching your hands toward your left foot. Lower with control and repeat. Focus on using your core to lift, not momentum.

name: Single Leg Pike Up (Right)
description: Lie on your back with arms extended overhead and legs straight. Keeping your left leg down, pike your right leg up while simultaneously lifting your torso, reaching your hands toward your right foot. Lower with control and repeat. Focus on using your core to lift, not momentum.

name: Single Leg Raise
description: Lie on your back with one leg flat on the floor and the other leg straight. Lift the straight leg up to 90 degrees while keeping the other foot anchored on the ground. Lower with control without touching the floor. Alternate legs. The grounded leg provides stability and allows focus on unilateral core control.

name: Single Leg RDL with Kettlebell
description: A single-leg Romanian deadlift holding a kettlebell for added resistance. Stand on your left leg holding a kettlebell in your right hand. Keep a soft bend in your standing knee. Hinge at the hips, extending your right leg straight behind you for counterbalance while lowering the kettlebell toward the floor. Keep your back flat and core engaged - your body should form a T-shape at the bottom. Lower until you feel a deep stretch in your standing leg hamstring. Squeeze your glute to return to standing. Complete all reps on one side before switching. The kettlebell adds load while challenging balance and single-leg stability.

name: Sit-up Leg Crunch
description: Lie on your back with legs extended. As you sit up, simultaneously bring your knees toward your chest, crunching your torso and legs together at the top. Lower both your upper body and legs back down with control. Combines a full sit-up with a knee tuck for comprehensive ab engagement.

name: Skin the Cat
description: A fundamental gymnastics movement that builds shoulder mobility and strength through a full rotation. Hang from rings or a bar. Lift your legs up and thread them between your arms, continuing to rotate backwards until your body passes through and you're in a 'German hang' position (hanging with arms behind you). Pause briefly, then reverse the movement to return to the starting hang. Keep arms straight throughout and move slowly with control. This builds the shoulder extension flexibility and strength needed for back levers and muscle-ups. Prerequisites: comfortable dead hang, hanging leg raises, and decent shoulder mobility. Start with bent knees (tuck) before progressing to straight legs.

name: Slow Crunch
description: Lie on your back with knees bent, feet flat on the floor. With hands behind your head, slowly lift shoulders off the ground over 2-3 seconds. Pause at the top, then slowly lower back down over 2-3 seconds. Focus on controlled tempo.

name: Slow Flutter Kicks
description: Lie on your back with legs extended. Lift shoulders slightly off the ground. Slowly alternate kicking your legs up and down in a controlled flutter motion, maintaining constant tension in the core without touching the ground.

name: Slow Mountain Climbers
description: Start in high plank position. Slowly bring one knee toward your chest with control, then return to plank. Alternate sides slowly and deliberately, focusing on core tension and controlled movement over speed.

name: Smith Machine Bench Press
description: Position a flat bench under the Smith machine bar. Lie with eyes under the bar, feet flat on floor. Grip bar slightly wider than shoulder-width. Unhook and lower to mid-chest, then press back up to near lockout. The guided path allows you to bench safely without a spotter. Great for building pressing strength.

name: Smith Machine Bent-Over Squat
description: A squat variation on the smith machine where the torso stays bent forward throughout the movement, similar to a squat/good-morning hybrid. Position under the smith bar with a wider-than-shoulder stance. Keep torso hinged forward (nearly parallel to ground) while squatting down and up. The guided bar path provides stability for this unusual position. Heavily loads the posterior chain and quads simultaneously. Inspired by @powerbrutehq - non-standard form, use caution and start light.

name: Smith Machine Bulgarian Split Squat
description: Position bar across upper back under the Smith machine. Place rear foot on a bench behind you. Take a forward step so your front knee stays over your ankle at the bottom. Unhook the bar and lower until your rear knee nearly touches the floor. Drive through the front heel to return. The guided bar path provides stability while still challenging single-leg strength. Complete all reps on one side, then switch legs.

name: Smith Machine Calf Raise
description: Position bar across upper back. Stand on a raised surface (plate or step) with balls of feet on edge, heels hanging off. Unhook bar and lower heels for a full stretch. Press through balls of feet to rise as high as possible, squeezing calves. Lower with control. The guided bar provides stability for this challenging exercise.

name: Smith Machine Close Grip Press
description: Lie on a flat bench under the Smith machine. Grip the bar with hands shoulder-width apart or slightly narrower. Unhook and lower bar to lower chest, keeping elbows tucked close to your body. Press up powerfully. The close grip shifts emphasis from chest to triceps.

name: Smith Machine Front Squat
description: Position bar across the front of your shoulders, elbows high. Cross your arms to grip the bar or use a clean grip. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, slightly in front of the bar. Unhook and descend, keeping torso upright and elbows high. Drive through heels to stand. Front position emphasizes quads more than back squat.

name: Smith Machine Good Morning
description: Position bar across upper back (not on neck). Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, soft bend in knees. Unhook the bar and brace your core. Push hips back while keeping back flat, lowering torso until nearly parallel to floor. Feel the stretch in hamstrings. Drive hips forward to return. The guided bar path helps maintain form while loading the posterior chain. Start light to master the movement.

name: Smith Machine Hip Thrust
description: Position a bench perpendicular to the Smith machine. Sit on the floor with your upper back against the bench edge. Roll the bar to your hip crease. Plant feet flat on the floor, hip-width apart. Unhook bar and drive through heels, squeezing glutes at the top until your body forms a straight line from shoulders to knees. Lower with control.

name: Smith Machine Incline Press
description: Set bench to 30-45 degree incline under the Smith machine. Grip bar slightly wider than shoulder width. Unhook and lower bar to upper chest with control. Press up to full arm extension without locking elbows. The incline angle targets upper chest and front delts more than flat pressing.

name: Smith Machine Inverted Row
description: Set bar at about waist height. Hang underneath with arms extended, gripping bar overhand. Keep body straight from heels to shoulders. Pull chest to bar by squeezing shoulder blades together. Lower with control. Adjust bar height - lower bar = harder. Great for building up to pull-ups.

name: Smith Machine Lunge
description: Position bar across upper back. Step one foot forward under the bar, the other behind. Unhook and lower until both knees are at 90 degrees. Drive through front heel to stand. Complete all reps on one leg, then switch. The guided bar path provides stability, letting you focus on depth and balance. Great for building single-leg strength.

name: Smith Machine Romanian Deadlift
description: Stand facing the bar with feet hip-width apart. Grip bar just outside your thighs. Unhook and stand tall. Push hips back while keeping legs nearly straight (soft knee bend). Lower bar along thighs until you feel a deep hamstring stretch. Drive hips forward to return. The guided bar path helps maintain proper form.

name: Smith Machine Bent-Over Row
description: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Hinge at hips until torso is roughly 45 degrees. Grip the bar slightly wider than shoulder-width. Unhook and row the bar toward your lower chest, driving elbows back and squeezing shoulder blades. Lower with control. The guided path helps maintain consistent form throughout the movement.

name: Smith Machine Shoulder Press
description: Set an incline bench at about 85-90 degrees under the Smith machine. Sit with bar starting at shoulder height. Grip slightly wider than shoulders, unhook and press overhead until arms are nearly straight. Lower with control to shoulder level. The guided path helps maintain proper form and allows you to press safely without a spotter.

name: Smith Machine Split Squat
description: Position bar across upper back. Take a split stance with one foot forward, one back. Both feet should be far enough that front knee stays over ankle at bottom. Unhook and lower until back knee nearly touches floor. Drive through front heel to stand. Complete all reps on one side, then switch legs.

name: Smith Machine Squat
description: Position the bar across your upper back (not neck). Stand with feet slightly in front of the bar path, shoulder-width apart. Unhook the bar and descend by pushing hips back and bending knees until thighs are parallel. Drive through your heels to stand. The guided bar path helps maintain balance and allows you to focus on depth and form.

name: Smith Machine Step Up
description: Position bar across upper back under the Smith machine. Place a box or bench in front of you at knee height. Unhook the bar, place one foot fully on the platform, then drive through that heel to step up. Bring the trailing foot up briefly, then step back down with control. The guided bar path allows you to load heavy while maintaining balance. Complete all reps on one leg, then switch.

name: Smith Machine Sumo Squat
description: Position bar across upper back. Take a wide stance with toes pointed out 45 degrees. Unhook and descend by pushing knees out over toes and sitting back. Go as deep as mobility allows while keeping chest up. Drive through heels to stand. Sumo stance emphasizes inner thighs and glutes.

name: Snap Kicks
description: Lie on your back with shoulders slightly lifted and hands by your sides or under your hips. Rapidly snap one leg up toward the ceiling then back down while the other stays low, alternating with quick, sharp movements. Focus on speed and precision - each kick should be a quick snap, not a slow lift. Keep core engaged throughout to protect lower back.

name: Soleus Pushup
description: Sit on the floor (or chair) with feet flat on the floor and muscles relaxed. The heel rises naturally while the front of the foot stays put - this is a passive movement, not an active lift. When the heel reaches the top of its range of motion, passively release it to come back down. The aim is to simultaneously shorten the calf muscle while the soleus is naturally activated by its motor neurons. Keep the gastrocnemius relaxed - you can place your hand on the back of your calf near the knee to ensure it doesn't flex. This targets the soleus muscle specifically, which is important for metabolic health and ankle stability.

name: Spiderman Plank
description: Start in high plank position. Bring right knee toward right elbow, keeping hips level. Return to plank and repeat on left side. This targets obliques while challenging core stability.

name: Split Squat
description: Stand in a staggered stance with one foot forward and one back. Lower your back knee toward the ground while keeping your front knee over your ankle. Push through your front foot to return to standing. Complete all reps on one side before switching.

name: Barbell Back Squat
description: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, barbell across upper back. Lower by bending knees and hips until thighs are parallel to ground. Stand back up.

name: Squat with Arm Raise
description: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, arms at your sides (can hold light dumbbells for added resistance). As you descend into a squat, simultaneously raise your arms straight out in front of you to shoulder height. At the bottom of the squat, your thighs should be parallel to the ground and arms extended forward. As you stand up, lower your arms back to your sides. This combination movement elevates heart rate and works both lower and upper body.

name: Squat Jumps
description: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Lower into a squat with thighs parallel to floor, then explosively jump as high as possible. Swing arms for momentum. Land softly with bent knees and immediately lower into the next squat.

name: Squat Kick
description: Combine a squat with an alternating front kick for cardio and leg strength. Lower into a squat position with thighs parallel to the ground. As you stand up explosively, kick one leg straight out in front of you at hip height. Return foot to ground and immediately squat again, kicking with the opposite leg on the next rep. Keep your core tight and chest up throughout. The kick challenges balance and engages hip flexors while the squat works the lower body.

name: Squat Sky Reaches
description: Start in a deep squat position. Place one hand on the ground for support. Rotate your torso and reach the other arm up toward the ceiling, following your hand with your eyes. Hold briefly, then switch sides. Can be done assisted by holding onto something for balance.

name: Squat to Calf Raise
description: A squat variation that adds a calf raise at the top of the movement. Lower into a full squat with thighs parallel to the ground, keeping weight in your heels. Drive up to standing, and at the top of the movement, rise onto the balls of your feet into a calf raise, squeezing your calves at the peak. Lower heels back to the ground with control before beginning the next squat. This combination builds lower body strength while adding calf work and improving ankle stability.

name: Squat to Stand
description: A dynamic mobility exercise that prepares the body for squatting. Start standing with feet shoulder-width apart. Lower into a deep squat position, going as low as your mobility allows while keeping feet flat on the ground. In the bottom position, you can place your hands on the floor for support if needed. From the deep squat, stand back up to the starting position. Repeat this movement smoothly, focusing on maintaining good form throughout. This exercise improves ankle dorsiflexion, hip mobility, and lower back flexibility while warming up the muscles used in squatting. Great as part of a squat warmup routine.

name: Stacked Leg Ups
description: Lie on your back with legs stacked on top of each other (crossed at ankles). Lift both legs straight up toward the ceiling, then lower them slowly without touching the floor. The stacked position adds an element of hip stability and slightly changes the angle of engagement.

name: Stand to Push-up Walk
description: A dynamic movement flowing from standing to push-up and back. Start standing tall with feet hip-width apart. Hinge at the hips and place your hands on the floor in front of your feet. Walk your hands forward until you reach a push-up position. Perform one push-up (optional - can skip for warmup). Walk your hands back toward your feet, keeping legs as straight as possible. Stand back up to the starting position. This combines the inchworm with push-up work, building upper body strength while dynamically stretching the hamstrings. Great as a warm-up or as part of a bodyweight circuit.

name: Standing Leg Lift
description: Stand upright and lift one leg straight up in front of you as high as comfortable while keeping your torso upright and core engaged. Lower with control and repeat. This is like a standing leg raise, great for warming up the hip flexors and core. Can hold onto something for balance if needed.

name: Star Situps
description: Lie on your back with arms and legs extended in a star position. Perform a situp while bringing your hands to your toes, creating a V-shape with your body. Return to starting position.

name: Step Up
description: Stand facing a box or bench that's about knee height. Place one foot fully on the platform. Drive through the heel of the elevated foot to step up onto the platform, bringing the other foot up to meet it. Step back down with the same leg leading, or alternate legs. Hold dumbbells at sides, a kettlebell at chest, a barbell across back, or use a Smith machine for added resistance. Keep your chest up and core engaged throughout.

name: Stomach Vacuum Hold
description: The classic bodybuilding exercise for targeting the transverse abdominis - your deepest core muscle that acts like a natural weight belt. Can be performed lying down, on all fours, seated, or standing. For the LYING version: Lie on your back with knees bent, feet flat. EXHALE ALL your air completely - push every last bit out. At the bottom of your exhale, draw your belly button IN and UP toward your spine as hard as you can, as if trying to touch your belly button to your backbone. You should feel your waist narrowing and your abdomen becoming hollow/concave. HOLD this position for the prescribed time (30 seconds) while taking small, shallow breaths through your chest only - do NOT let your belly expand. It will burn. Release and breathe normally between sets. For QUADRUPED version: Start on hands and knees, let your belly hang, exhale completely, then suck everything in and hold. This is harder because gravity is working against you. Key: This is NOT sucking in your gut superficially - it's a deep internal drawing-in sensation.

name: Straddle Back Lever
description: An advanced back lever progression with straight legs spread wide. From German hang or inverted hang, lower your body with straight legs spread apart until your back is parallel to the ground. Arms are straight and behind you. The wider the straddle, the shorter the lever and the easier it is. Keep your entire body in one plane - don't let your hips pike or sag. This position demands significant shoulder flexibility, straight-arm strength, and core tension. The shoulders are in a vulnerable extended position, so ensure you've built up through tuck and advanced tuck progressions first. Hold for time, working toward 10-15 seconds before attempting full back lever.

name: Straddle Front Lever
description: An advanced front lever progression with legs spread wide. From a dead hang, engage your lats powerfully and raise your body until your back is parallel to the ground with arms straight. Legs are straight and spread wide apart (straddled). The wider the straddle, the easier it is - narrow your stance as you get stronger. Keep your body in one straight plane from hands through hips. Shoulders stay depressed, lats fully engaged. Don't let hips pike up or sag down. This requires significant lat strength, core tension, and body control. Hold for time - even 5 seconds is impressive. Master this before attempting full front lever with legs together.

name: Straddle Hold
description: From lying on your back, lift your torso and spread legs wide into a straddle, holding at the top. Balance on your sit bones with legs elevated and arms reaching forward or between legs. Maintain the V-shape with legs wide apart, engaging inner thighs and core. Common in dance conditioning for developing hip flexibility alongside core strength.

name: Straddle Pike Up
description: Lie on your back with arms extended overhead and legs spread wide in a straddle position. Pike up by lifting your torso and legs simultaneously, reaching your hands between your legs or toward your feet. Lower with control, maintaining the straddle throughout. This variation challenges hip flexibility and inner thigh engagement.

name: Straddle Planche
description: An advanced planche with straight legs spread wide. From floor or parallettes, lean forward with straight arms until you can lift your body horizontal to the ground. Legs are straight and spread wide in a straddle. The wider the straddle, the easier due to the shorter lever arm. Body should form a straight line from head through hips. Shoulders are protracted, arms locked straight. This requires exceptional pushing strength - particularly in the anterior deltoids - plus total body tension. The balance point is precise; too far forward and you fall, not far enough and you can't hold the position. Master advanced tuck planche (10-15 seconds) before attempting. Even a 3-5 second hold is impressive.

name: Straddle Sit Stretch
description: Sit on the floor with legs spread as wide as comfortable in a straddle position. Keep your legs straight and toes pointing up. Fold forward from the hips, reaching your hands out in front of you or toward one leg at a time. Hold each position for 30-60 seconds. This stretches the inner thighs (adductors) and hamstrings. Essential for developing the flexibility needed for straddle holds and pancake stretches.

name: Straddle Snaps
description: Lie on your back with arms overhead. Quickly snap your legs apart into a wide straddle while lifting your torso, then snap them back together while lowering down. Move rapidly between the open straddle position and the closed flat position. This combines the straddle pattern with explosive speed, challenging both flexibility and power.

name: Straddle Tuck Compression
description: Lie on your back with legs spread wide in a straddle position, arms overhead. Engage your hip flexors and core to pull your legs up and together while crunching your upper body toward your legs, bringing everything into a compressed tuck at the top. Lower with control back to the straddle position. This builds the hip flexor strength and compression needed for L-sits and straddle holds.

name: Straight Arm Pulldown
description: Stand facing a cable machine with a straight bar or rope attachment at the high pulley. Grab the attachment with straight arms, hands shoulder-width apart. Hinge slightly at the hips and keep a small bend in your elbows. Pull the bar down toward your thighs in an arc, keeping arms straight throughout. Squeeze your lats hard at the bottom. Control the weight back up, feeling the stretch in your lats. This is a pure lat isolation movement - keep your arms straight to take biceps out of the equation.

name: Straight Leg Raises
description: Lie on your back with legs straight. Lift both legs together to about 45 degrees, pause, then lower without touching the floor. Keep legs straight throughout and lower back pressed to the floor. Very effective for lower ab engagement.

name: Suitcase Squat
description: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell or kettlebell in one hand at your side like a suitcase. Keep your shoulders level and core engaged - resist the urge to lean toward the weighted side. Squat down by pushing your hips back and bending your knees, keeping your chest up and the weight at your side. Descend until your thighs are parallel to the ground. Drive through your heels to stand. The asymmetric load challenges your core and obliques to maintain balance.

name: Sumo Deadlift
description: Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width apart, toes pointed out at 45 degrees. Position the barbell over midfoot, closer to your shins than conventional deadlift. Grip the bar with hands inside your legs, using a mixed or double overhand grip. Keep your chest up and back straight. Drive through your heels and push your knees out as you extend your hips and knees simultaneously to lift the bar. The wide stance emphasizes inner thighs, glutes, and allows for a more upright torso position compared to conventional deadlift.

name: Superman
description: Lie face down with arms extended overhead and legs straight. Simultaneously lift your arms, chest, and legs off the floor, squeezing your glutes and back muscles. Hold briefly at the top, then lower with control.

name: Supine Hip Abduction (Leg Drops)
description: A core stability exercise that challenges your ability to maintain a stable pelvis while moving your legs sideways. Lie on your back with knees bent at 90 degrees, feet lifted so your shins are parallel to the ceiling (tabletop position). Keep your arms by your sides for stability. First, engage your deep core - exhale and gently draw your belly button toward your spine. MAINTAINING core engagement, slowly let one knee drop out to the side (abduction) while keeping the other knee pointing straight up. Only go as far as you can while keeping your pelvis level and lower back neutral - you should feel NO rotation in your spine. Return the leg to center and repeat on the other side. Move SLOWLY and with control. The challenge is keeping your pelvis rock-solid while your legs move. If you feel your back arching or your pelvis tilting, reduce your range of motion. Each leg drop = 1 rep. Alternate sides.

name: Supine Leg Slides (Heel Slides)
description: A foundational dead bug progression that teaches core stability during leg movement. Lie on your back with knees bent, feet flat on floor. First, find your neutral spine position - there should be a small natural curve in your lower back (you could slide your hand under). Gently engage your deep core by exhaling and drawing your belly button slightly toward your spine WITHOUT flattening your back. MAINTAINING this core engagement, slowly slide one heel along the floor to extend that leg fully, then slide it back to the start position. The KEY is keeping your pelvis completely still and your lower back in neutral - no rocking, no arching, no flattening. If your back arches as the leg extends, you've gone too far. Alternate legs. Move SLOWLY - this is about control, not speed. Each leg extension = 1 rep. Breathe naturally throughout, exhaling as you extend.

name: Support Hold
description: Support yourself at the top of the dip position on parallel bars or between two sturdy chairs. Keep arms straight, shoulders depressed (away from ears), and core tight. Hold this position with good posture. This builds the strength foundation for dips.

name: Toe Touches
description: Lie on your back with legs extended straight up toward the ceiling. Crunch up and reach your hands toward your toes. Lower back down with control and repeat.

name: Toes to Bar
description: An advanced hanging core exercise where your toes touch the pull-up bar. Hang from a bar with arms extended and shoulders active. Initiate a slight kip by pushing the bar away and creating a small swing. As you swing back, engage your lats and core to pull your hips up while raising straight legs. Touch your toes (or shins) to the bar between your hands. Lower with control and repeat. The strict version eliminates the kip - raise legs using only core and hip flexor strength. This requires significant core compression strength, hip flexor power, and grip endurance. Master hanging leg raises and L-hangs before attempting. Common in CrossFit and gymnastics training.

name: Tree Pose (Vrksasana)
description: Stand on one leg. Place the sole of your other foot on your inner thigh or calf (never on the knee). Bring hands to heart center or extend overhead. Find a fixed point to focus your gaze. Engage your standing leg and core for stability. Hold and breathe, then switch sides.

name: Triangle Pose (Trikonasana)
description: Stand with feet wide apart (about 3-4 feet). Turn your right foot out 90 degrees and left foot slightly in. Extend arms parallel to the floor. Hinge at your right hip and reach your right hand down toward your right ankle (or shin), while extending your left arm straight up toward the ceiling. Keep both legs straight and gaze up at your raised hand. Stack your shoulders vertically. Hold, then switch sides. Stretches the hamstrings, opens the hips, and lengthens the side body.

name: Tricep Dip
description: Sit on the edge of a bench or sturdy chair with hands gripping the edge beside your hips. Slide your hips off the edge with legs extended or bent at 90 degrees for easier variation. Lower your body by bending elbows to about 90 degrees, keeping elbows pointed back. Push through your palms to return to start. Keep your back close to the bench throughout.

name: Tricep Extension
description: Stand or sit holding a dumbbell with both hands behind your head, elbows pointing up. Extend your arms to raise the weight overhead, keeping upper arms stationary. Lower the weight behind your head with control. Keep elbows close to your head throughout.

name: Tripod Headstand Leg Raises to Push-up
description: Start in tripod headstand position with head and both hands forming a triangle base. Lower one leg toward the ground while maintaining balance, then raise it back up. After 10 leg movements, transition smoothly down through a pike position and immediately perform a push-up. Return to tripod headstand and repeat. This combines inversion strength, core control, and pushing power in one movement.

name: Tuck Back Lever
description: The first progression toward a full back lever. Start by performing a skin the cat to get into German hang position. From German hang, pull your tucked knees up toward your chest and lift your hips until your back is parallel to the ground. Arms are straight and behind you, body inverted with knees tucked tight. Hold this position. This requires shoulder extension flexibility and strength in a vulnerable position. Make sure you're comfortable with German hang before attempting. Focus on keeping arms straight and maintaining body tension. Start with short holds (5-10 seconds) and progress gradually. Don't force depth if shoulders feel strained.

name: Tuck Front Lever
description: The first progression toward a full front lever. Hang from a bar or rings with straight arms. Pull your knees to your chest in a tight tuck position. Using your lats and core, rotate your body backwards until your back is parallel to the ground - like an upside-down plank but with bent knees. Your arms should be straight and perpendicular to your torso. Hold this position. Focus on depressing your shoulders (pulling them away from ears) and squeezing your lats hard. Keep your hips in line with your shoulders - don't let them sag. Start with 5-10 second holds and build up. This builds the pulling strength foundation for advanced front lever progressions.

name: Tuck Hold
description: Sit with knees bent into your chest, arms wrapped around your shins or reaching forward. Lift your feet off the floor and balance on your sit bones, keeping your spine rounded and core engaged. Hold this tucked position while maintaining steady breathing. This is a prerequisite for L-sits and more advanced holds.

name: Tuck Planche
description: The first true planche progression with feet off the ground. Start in a planche lean position with hands on floor or parallettes.
