Lean forward aggressively, shifting your weight over your hands until your shoulders are well past your fingertips. Keep arms straight. Tuck your knees tight to your chest and lift your feet off the ground. Hold this position with your back rounded and hips at or slightly above shoulder height. The key is the forward lean - without it, you cannot balance. Keep protracted shoulders (push them forward) and maintain whole-body tension. Start with short holds (3-5 seconds) and build up. Prerequisites: 60-second planche lean, solid push-up strength, and good wrist conditioning.

name: Tuck Snaps
description: Lie on your back with arms overhead. Explosively snap your knees to your chest while simultaneously crunching your torso up, then quickly extend back out to full length. The movement should be rapid - snap in, snap out. Think of your body as a spring, quickly compressing and extending. This builds explosive core power used in dance and acrobatics.

name: Typewriter Pull-up
description: An advanced pull-up variation where you move horizontally at the top of the movement. Use a wide grip on the bar. Pull up until your chin is over the bar. While holding at the top, shift your body horizontally from one hand to the other - as you move toward one hand, that arm bends more while the other straightens. Move back and forth like a typewriter carriage. This is extremely demanding, requiring you to support most of your weight on one arm at each end. It's an excellent progression toward one-arm pull-ups. Lower and repeat, or continue typing for multiple passes.

name: Upright Row
description: Stand holding dumbbells in front of your thighs with palms facing your body. Pull the weights straight up along your body, leading with your elbows, until they reach chest height. Lower with control. Keep the weights close to your body throughout.

name: V-Sit
description: Lie on your back with arms extended overhead. Simultaneously lift your legs and torso, reaching your hands toward your toes to form a 'V' shape. Balance on your glutes at the top, then lower back down with control. Keep your legs as straight as possible throughout the movement.

name: V-Tucks (Seated Knee Tucks)
description: A controlled core exercise that's a gentler version of the full V-up. Sit on the floor with your knees bent, feet flat, hands placed slightly behind your hips for support (fingers pointing forward or out to sides). Lean back slightly to about 45 degrees - you should feel your abs engage to hold this position. Lift your feet off the floor with knees still bent, shins roughly parallel to the ground - this is your starting position. Now perform the tuck: EXHALE and bring your knees toward your chest while simultaneously leaning your torso slightly forward to meet them, creating a 'V' shape with your body. INHALE and extend back to the starting position with legs out (knees can stay slightly bent) and torso leaning back. Move with CONTROL - do not use momentum or swing. The key is maintaining constant core tension throughout the movement. Keep your spine in a neutral position (not rounded) and your chest lifted. Each tuck-and-extend = 1 rep. To make it easier, keep feet lightly touching the floor between reps. To make it harder, keep legs fully extended.

name: V-Ups
description: Lie flat on back with arms extended overhead. Simultaneously lift legs and torso, reaching hands toward toes to form a V shape. Lower back down with control. Keep legs and arms straight throughout the movement.

name: Vertical Band Push
description: An overhead press using a resistance band for shoulder strengthening. Stand on the center of a resistance band with feet shoulder-width apart. Hold the band handles or ends at shoulder height with palms facing forward. Press straight up overhead until arms are fully extended, keeping your core tight and avoiding arching your back. Lower with control back to shoulder height. The band provides accommodating resistance - harder at the top of the movement when the band is most stretched. Great for building overhead pressing strength, shoulder stability, and as a warm-up before heavier pressing work.

name: Walkout with Straight Legs
description: Stand with feet hip-width apart. Bend at the hips and place your hands on the floor in front of your feet, keeping your legs as straight as possible. Walk your hands forward while maintaining straight legs, shifting your weight onto your hands. Continue walking forward until your body forms a straight line from shoulders to heels (plank position). Keep your core braced, glutes squeezed, and back flat throughout. Hold briefly at the plank position, then walk your hands back toward your feet, still keeping legs straight. Return to standing. This exercise dynamically stretches the hamstrings while warming up the core and shoulders. Focus on maintaining straight legs throughout - if your hamstrings feel tight, continue breathing and work within your range of motion.

name: Wall Headstand Leg Raises
description: Perform a headstand against a wall for support. With control, lower both legs down toward the ground (pike position) then raise them back to vertical. Keep your core extremely tight throughout. This is intense core work in an inverted position. The wall provides safety but try to minimize contact with it as you build strength.

name: Wall Push-up
description: Stand facing a wall at arm's length. Place hands on the wall at shoulder height and width. Bend elbows to bring your chest toward the wall, then push back to starting position. Keep body straight throughout.

name: Warrior I (Virabhadrasana I)
description: Step one foot back into a lunge position, keeping back foot at 45 degrees. Bend front knee to 90 degrees while keeping back leg straight. Raise arms overhead with palms facing each other. Square hips forward and lift chest. Hold and breathe deeply, then switch sides.

name: Warrior II (Virabhadrasana II)
description: Step feet wide apart. Turn right foot out 90 degrees. Bend right knee over ankle while keeping left leg straight. Extend arms parallel to floor, gaze over front hand. Keep torso centered between legs.

name: Weighted Bridge Lift
description: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat. Hold a dumbbell or kettlebell on your hips. Lift hips into a bridge position, then raise one leg straight up while holding the weight steady. Alternate legs with control.

name: Weighted Crunch
description: Lie on your back with knees bent. Hold a dumbbell or weight plate across your chest. Engage your core and lift shoulders off the ground, bringing your chest toward your knees against the weight. Lower with control.

name: Weighted Single Leg Bridge
description: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on floor. Hold a dumbbell or weight with both hands straight up above your chest. Lift your hips into a bridge position. Extend one leg straight while keeping hips level. Hold the bridge with one leg raised while keeping the weight pressed up. Lower and switch legs. Great for glutes, hamstrings, and core stability.

name: Wide Crunches
description: Lie on your back with legs extended wide apart. Bring your legs up toward your chest while crunching your core. Return to starting position with control.

name: Wide Grip Cable Row
description: Sit at the cable row machine with a wide grip attachment. Place your feet on the platform and extend your arms fully. Grip the wide bar with hands wider than shoulder-width. Pull the bar toward your upper chest, leading with your elbows and squeezing your shoulder blades together. This wider grip emphasizes the upper back and rear deltoids. Control the weight back to the starting position.

name: Wide Grip Pull-up
description: A pull-up variation with hands placed wider than shoulder width to emphasize the lats. Hang from a pull-up bar with hands 1.5x shoulder-width apart, palms facing away (overhand grip). Engage your shoulder blades by pulling them down and back. Pull yourself up by driving your elbows down toward your hips until your chin clears the bar. Focus on squeezing your lats at the top. Lower with control to full arm extension. The wider grip increases lat activation and reduces bicep involvement compared to standard pull-ups. This is sometimes called a shoulder pull-up because of the wider hand position.

name: Wide Push-ups
description: Place hands wider than shoulder-width apart, fingers pointing forward or slightly outward. Lower chest to the floor while keeping elbows at about 45 degrees. Push back up. The wide stance increases chest activation.

name: Wide Row
description: Perform a horizontal row with hands placed wider than shoulder-width apart. This emphasizes the rear deltoids and rhomboids. Keep elbows flared out slightly as you pull chest to bar.

name: Yuri's Shoulder Band Warmup
description: Hold a resistance band with both hands, arms extended in front. Pull the band apart while raising arms overhead and behind you in a smooth arc. Return the same way. Keep arms straight throughout. Alternative: Use a towel or stick for shoulder dislocates.
